posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529838
I wouldn't even be sure where to point you to get started, this is one of those subjects that can be both very simple and insanely complicated at the same time, you can't really learn without just doing it.

In my case I'm a full time CNC Programmer during the day, so the actual CAD/CAM/Operation side of things wasn't a real concern. I initially bought one of those eBay special 3018 routers which I used to get familiar with Mach and the electrical hardware side of the deal. I figured if I crashed or bricked it it wouldn't be a huge write-off, I also found it was useful for debugging purposes while doing the conversion on the Bridgeport. From there it's really just a matter of making sure you size everything correctly for the machine you're intending to drive, it's all more or less Legos, just read the manuals and take it one step at a time.

I would not attempt anything with a full sized machine as a first project unless you're a fairly competent tinkerer/fabricator and have a bit of cash. I'm not trying to say it's crazy expensive, but there's a very real possibility that you make a mistake and smoke a $2-300 motion controller/BOB/VFD/ect, if that would sink the project this might not be for you. That being said, because everything is off the shelf it's generally way cheaper than "Proper" CNC components, my entire setup cost less than the replacement servo drive for one of the horizontals I used to run.

For the CAD/CAM side of things just downloading a cheap software to play around with is a good start. If you learn one software and are competent with it you've practically learned them all. Fusion 360 is free for hobbiests if I remember correctly, which comes with free basic CAM functionality as well. To play around with it I would get a cheap router like >>2529933 did. Just play around with plastics and wood with increasingly complex parts and such. Good way to practice too is to learn the g code by manually coding it yourself at first, then using CAM once you start getting into 3D toolpaths. Gives you actual appreciation for the software and let's you know what the hell you're looking at if you have to edit the code it spits out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529252
>What you want to keep an eye out for is for one of the older knee type CNC mills, think like a Proto-Trak

Golden advice.^ I strongly recommend taking a community college machining course BEFORE buying a machine tool and while there go beyond the curriculum and volunteer which is a great way to get personal machine time. I did that with machining and welding programs and worked for the school afterwards. If I didn't have severe chronic pain I'd still be there. Many schools hire from within like they did my bro who I encouraged to take the course.

Don't be afraid to train formally for anything. I've decades in mechanics, aviation, and much more. I've taken and taught classes and learned a shitload both ways. Machining training gives you a serious edge and profoundly changes the way you relate to metal, machines and the world around you.

My pro machinistbro is rich in no small part due to two CNC open knee mills. They're amazingly versatile.

I suggest taking CAD first unless you're already proficient since once you know CAD you can think in CAD.

>>2529957
I would visit local machine shops and ask what they want to see in an ideal student or apprentice. I promise you'll surprise the shit out of them which can open doors. That way you can study what they use which may get you a job one day. If not it never hurts to network. I fix computers for my bros shop and get all sorts of leftovers for my home shop. He let me use his manual machines after I'd gone to school and hired several people from it.

Machining is a mentoring culture where they understand only true enthusiasts should be machinists. Stop by some Friday afternoon and if they're busy offer to come back because determination is so rare these days. Be chill, friendly but listen more than talk. If you hit it off perhaps you can do chores like cleaning up the shop (which is everybody's job, not hard at all and lets you get up close to get a visual and some tactile appreciation of the equipment.

CAM stands for Computer Aided Machining. Basically when you upload a model into CAM you just tell the software what tools/toolpaths to use and it spits out g code for you. I've got the part that had me stumped figured out. I cut the fingers off a cotton glove and stretched them over a plaster cast of my nubs that were wrapped in electrical tape, using the same technique as Ian Davis. And I drenched them in like 3 coats of fiberglass resin. I have some 3d printed pieces that I assembled and coated in silicone for grip.
Then I spent all evening sanding down the now hardened fiberglass outer sockets, so they'd be wearable and comfortable. Using JB Weld plastic epoxy, I glued on the 3d printed parts (from the Ivan Owen set on thingiverse, its more robust than Knick Fingers due to only having 1 hinge instead of 2)
Now I'm going to make the same 3d printed wrist anchor and backhand "tendon" guide as the Snake hand. The last thing I'll need is a way to affix these parts to my hand. I hate wearing fingerless gloves because they get sweaty, I'm not a fan of having a band across the top of my palm, and velcro straps degrade too fast... It's the home stretch now though, I'm feeling pretty confident in this design

>but I figure there is some sort of thermocouple that senses when the pilot is lit, right? How do I trouble shoot this?
A lot of times they use a sense bulb if they don't have a thermocouple. Regardless, they can go bad and I've had to replace one before in a situation exactly like yours.

Trouble shooting--- are you sure there is enough gas pressure reaching the valve in the first place? If so, then suspect the sense bulb/thermocouple. If replacing it doesn't work, then you can replace the entire valve.

>>2530748
Instead of wall mounting I would find a U-boat dolly (so named for the conning tower of WWII submarines, you'll get the idea when you see the top of one moving in a grocery store) and modify it as a rolling workbench. Easy way is get two, cut off the top loops from one then place the second on the pipe upright (this will make instant sense when you see a U-boat dolly)

This pic is only for information. I would not pay new price. I got mine used (seven for 50 bucks each but I'd give 80 or 100 if I really needed one):

https://www.ebay.com/itm/233775859128

There are a variety of styles and they should exist in Europe etc. If not just copy the thing. I pulled the center wheel axle bolts so I can push my carts sideways at zero forward motion. You can see how easy it is to customize them.

Then you can roll it outdoors for outsize work or to do messy shit like sanding or grinding. You can mount toolboxes or racks or metal pegboard to it as a back. Whatever steams yer panties.

I use mine in my shipping container workshop where their narrow width is idea.

if it condenses on the window and not the wall
and you heat up the window
it won't just start to condense on the wall
it simply will not condense anywhere at all

if it condenses a little bit on the wall and a lot on the window
and you heat up the window
it will still only condense a little bit on the wall

the volume of moisture in the room relative to the size of the corner of a window is enormous.
water condensing on the window doesn't suddenly turn the room arid. the window is not a desiccant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528520
usually there is an external breaker box that cut powers to the entire house that is placed outdoors at the mains connection. This is to protect the house in the case a short happens before reaching the junction box, which is always inside the houses. I am not an electrician, so I don't know if this is a standard and true for all homes, but it is true in my case. If you want to replace the outdoor junction box, then you might have to call the power company if there isn't a cutoff siwtch somewherre.

It's still garbage. The ring pull tab isn't ancient, it was invented in the 1950s. It was discarded because drunks could swallow the tabs and they could cause cuts when sat or stepped on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527235
Lots of kids end up in humanities literally just because math and science are so poorly taught in high school. By the time they are in high school, most kids dislike math and science because they think they're too hard. They aren't hard, they've just been failed in one or more topics. Failing is a normal part of learning any subject, but schools don't give kids time to go back and retry things they didn't master the first time. So kids just accept that they "don't know" x subject and have to leave it at that because it's time to move on. Teachers have curriculum goals that they have to meet so that when standardized testing rolls around, enough kids can give enough right answers to keep the school funded.

Subjects like language arts and history are a lot harder to fail, because there's less to get wrong, so kids end up thinking these subjects are the only things they are "good" at. These subjects are often tested with essays read by human proctors, which are way more forgiving than multiple choice math and science.

When it comes time to graduate high school, theres enormous pressure on kids to go to college and pick a major. They, logically, want to pick a major they are likely to succeed at, so using their limited window into education and job training, they arrive at the conclusion that they have to take humanities.

In an ideal world, kids would learn hard subjects at their own pace, and take as much time to master subjects as they need. For many reasons this is extremely impractical for a system that needs to educate thousands of kids per county, but that's the result you get: kids who just think STEM isnt for them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523144
>Anybody here make their own cigarettes? Is its easy?
Yeah, it's easy to use the tube stuffing type machines if you don't want to hand roll them.
It's probably faster to use the stuffing machine too. I used the "topomatic" type machine.
>Cheaper then manufactured ones?
It's way way fucking cheaper. Do the math; you can get a pound of decent tobacco for like 15$ and tubes to go with it for another 5$ and make about 20 packs of cigarettes.
It'll probably average you around a dollar per pack or less.

One problem with doing this though is that the cigarettes won't be exactly like your favorite store brand. They won't taste exactly the same because cigarette manufacturers use a proprietary blend of flavors and treatments that is responsible for the distinct taste of their cigs. You can still find plenty of good quality, cheap tobacco (menthol, light, regular, extra bold, etc) but it will never be an exact match for your favorite brand.
Another thing is that these homemade ones will always burn just slightly differently than the industrial ones. Industrially made cigarettes are (AFAIK) made from a specially prepared reconstituted tobacco paper rather than shredded leaves. They do this to make things easier for their treatment steps, but also to make the mix have a 100% consistent texture and consistency that helps avoid problems with their processing and packing machinery. When you buy the cheap bags of raw tobacco, it's just leaves that have been cut/shredded to a consistency which is appropriate for rolling or tube packing cigs. So sometimes you may have a tiny inconsistency or packing error and wind up with a small void or an end of the tube that doesn't pack completely.

After you get familiar with the perfect amount of leaf to load in the machines chamber by doing a couple dozen cigs, you'll start to avoid this issue for the most part.

All in all, it's super cheap and easy to do and I'm always amazed that more smokers don't RYO

Anyway, a non-shit machine won't blink at any size you throw at it, it should effectively make no difference.
The little plastic shooters and mid-range one handed bandits are pretty shit, they struggle with everything and aren't worth your time.

If you're going to pop out almost 2 cartons worth per week, you're going to want something that'll keep up.
If you practice, and you get good and quick with a Top-o-Matic style injector or a handheld plastic one, sit down and do it all very rapidly in one sitting without taking a brake, that'll take about an hour.

A decent electric filler will save you so much time and effort it's worth joking about.
I have a hard time getting excited about 'em as I despise tubes and I'm probably faster with my rolling box (which isn't hand rolling, it's a fucking machine to do the work for you) than most faggots with a tube shooter.
If you want quantity though, a good electric filler is hard to beat.
It'll pay for itself anyway with the savings on smokes, and it'll pay for itself twice over versus the headaches of cheap shitty options.

Most out there are chinkanese, and some do actually suffer with longer tubes like you mentioned.
Handheld Plastic and Lever-Handle injectors are designed for specific sizes, and rarely perform well with any other size.
An electric that has adjustable pack/fill and has an oversized fill rod that can easily clear sizes beyond 100, that's what you want.
See if you have any local tobacco shops, as opposed to a smokeshop, decent chance they'll carry the same ones you find in the tobacco catalogs and you can actually get your eyes and hands on them instead of throwing darts online.

posts.com: I use to have a few hand crank rollers, they're shit the nut always loosens and there is no torque specs on it, has to be so lose but just the right tightness that it holds the bar together but they can still move to get it to work. They work great for a bit of usage then always have the same problem. I ended up buying an electronic one for a hundred dollars to test it out. Broke even in cost within 2 months, and actually had beer money left over after that. I kept having to travel for work and going out of town it wasn't practical to ever make enough to bring with and it was noticeable how fast buying packs would burn through cash. Even though it takes 5 minutes to make a pack worth of cigarettes with it usually it isn't worth the time compared to a tobacco pipe for me personally. Your mileage may vary. It was more than worth it for me the machines worked for over 5 years now (way more than I ever got out of hand crank ones) it's nice to be able to knock out a few really fast if I'm in the mood for a cig, and they're convenient when walking around outside and it's windy on the way between the bar to pick up a few drinks. It can be difficult getting consistency in how tightly they're packed, with hand cranks you can pack a tube so tighly you basically can't keep it lit, electronic ones will jam and you can't force it and have to break it up and go with much looser packing in cigarettes, so you want to smoke them if you got them otherwise they'll tend to shake loose while you're walking around. It's not a big deal if you got a hard case you can just throw the shake back into the machine and repack it, tear off the empty part of the tube that it fell out, it can be annoying if you got like 3 half cigarettes, but you get a sense for which ones will do that and to smoke them first. If you care to carry rolling papers on you, you can always just use that shake to make a rolley too, I like a rolley when no pipe but it's hard not to burn my stache with them.

>The powdered stuff that you snort. Dont know the name, never tried it.
That's snuff, and it's fucking awesome.

Ozona is the most widespread brand in the US.
Their Presidential is pretty unimpressive in my opinion, the Weiss and English are much better.
The C-Type (cherry) is what I'd recommend to most first-timers as an introduction to the stuff.
You sniff a small amount, a very small amount, into your nostrils.
Just the nostrils, you're not inhaling it, just barely getting it up in there.

Of every tobacco product out there that I've tried, snuff is the closest analogue to cigarettes as far as the high they provide.
You use very, very little tobacco, and it hits you like a freight train, then wears off quickly.
It's convenient as hell, a little tin in your pocket is much smaller than a pack of smokes and won't be ruined by manhandling, and you can use it wherever the fuck because it sure as hell isn't smoke, and that includes wherever the kids with vapes aren't allowed.

Ever needed a smoke in the middle of an unimpressive movie you're sitting through with some bitch?
Ever really needed a smoke on a long flight?
Stuck in a meeting for a whole day with one fucking lunch break and no chance to take 5 and puff one?

Go buy a tin of snuff from any decent tobacco shop, usually costs less than a half-decent pack of smokes.
I'm a pack-a-day smoker, and if I'm on a business trip I won't bother with smokes, a 5g tin of snuff lasts me 5 days.
It may not replace your current preference, it sure as shit has never replaced cigarettes or cigars for me, but it is a fucking awesome addition to the line-up.

It's also worth noting, it's basically guaranteed to make you sneeze.
You get over it quickly if you use the stuff regularly, but your first few times it's pretty much a certainty that you'll sneeze some nasty tobacco-laden ectoplasm.
Be ready with a tissue the first time you try it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Buy some thick plastic sheeting or tarps, enough to cover your greenhouse twice over, and buy some rolls of standard household fiberglass wall insulation, enough to cover the greenhouse once. Lay 1 layer of the plastic/tarp over the greenhouse, gluing the seams together. Then attach the fiberglass insulation to that layer of plastic with some spray adhesive. Then attach the second layer of plastic to the outside of the insulation with more spray adhesive. Glue the two sheets of plastic/tarp together around the edges. You now have a waterproof insulation blanket comprised of inexpensive materials you can buy at your local hardware store.

You can make it in sections if having it be 1 large blanket is too big to manage.

And if you want it to last, make sure whatever tarp or plastic sheeting you use is UV resistant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Air is a pretty decent insulator. Build a second greenhouse that's 12-18 inches larger in every dimension around the original greenhouse. This way your greenhouse can stay warm all the time and the sunlight can still get in without having to cover it with a blanket every night. This is the same principle that makes double pane windows so much better at insulating than single pane windows.

My fees broke down to cars being one price and SUV/Van/truck being a different price. I would either do the interior, the exterior or both. Interior I could usually do in 2 hours maybe 3. and exterior would take almost 4 hours. car interior was 100 and exterior was 125. For the van/truck/suv the fee was interior 125 and exterior 175. But this was 8 years ago, no idea what I would charge now

I had basic wash and wax stuff, and a machine buffer. For interior I had a vacuum and a steam cleaner. All my products were either meguairs or Griots. I always used microfiber cloths never rags. Microfiber cloths were thrown away after jobs I never washed them. On a full inside/outside I could usually get done in 6 or 7 hours. But if I had a van or something that was really fucked up it might take 8 hours.

Biggest tip is to take some before and afters and use social media as your word of mouth advertiser. Make damn sure that every single customer you work with posts something about you on either facebook or next-door and puts your phone number out there. Also get 500 flyers for your services off vista print.

No an LLC is a waste of time for the money you are gonna make. Just have them pay you cash and don't put the cash into the bank.

So you won't have a "floor," but still a surface to create your cubby. >>2529665's suggestion will give you a level surface if you REALLY need it, but if you're just talking about decorations, that shouldn't matter and having the full space to work with is probably more beneficial.

If those studs on the right have drywall on the other side, then I also suggest putting plywood on those as well to keep anything from pressing up against the interior wall, possibly cracking the drywall.

I was in charge at a tier 1 automotive company and we got a batch of about 2000 wire harness from Mexico where some were faulty but all required testing. The facility which produced the shitty harness also built a application specific continuity tester for this specific job, which also turned out to be faulty. There was a problem in the tester design where the green light would flash whether there was continuity in the harness or not. I caught it pretty early on and sent word up the chain but they assured me the testers were fine even though my multimeter was indicating otherwise and to finish the job. One of the big three received a batch of bad harnesses, which resulted in a shutdown of the line, which eventually rolled downhill to me. They "suspended" me indefinitely and that was that. Found a new job two days later and moved on.

>>2518885
It was the combination of a few factors, but the biggest one is called "dot gain". Colors are made by mixing size and location of dots in 4 different colors. Sort of like how digital screens mix RGB pixels together to create colors.

When you print those dots, there are factors that can make the dots larger or smaller than intended. In this case the paper it was printed on absorbed the ink more, creating larger dots. There might have been other factors, I don't know.

The ad was already very dark and moody looking to begin with. I did one quick pre-press at a local printer, and it came out dark... I had them lighten it a bit and due to time/money had to send the files right away.

I was really proud of the ad. It was my first "big" print ad, and I also handled the photography and design from top to bottom. Like, I was planning on framing a copy of it lol.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526941
>Why do people not to this?
I've done it... like the other anon said they are inferior on carpet without a beater bar.
They're sized for large tasks/loads and for typical home use that creates a few drawbacks-
- Not easy to empty into containers smaller than a shop/ yard style can
- more effort and hassle to dump the large barrel, but if you wait until it's full it can pick up odors, especially if you have pets
- usually don't have any way to see fill level without opening, which makes a mess
- they usually have shitty exhaust filtration and direction for use in a living space compared to a dedicated residential vac...I had to make a snorkel to direct the exhaust up or else it would blow papers and small items off of desks and low tables, blow dust and lint further under furniture and into corners the second you turned it on, toss blinds and curtains around, etc.
-We have dogs so after a while even with careful cleaning/ disinfecting it just pumped out dog bed smell that made it impossible to take into other peoples homes when doing remodel/ repair work.
-Finally the tools tend to be pretty limited, expensive when they arent, and thevtools and especially hoses are sized for shop and industrial spaces and can be unwieldy in tight areas or where you have nice finishes you dont want to bang up.
I have both now and except for cleanup after doing carpentry or drywall work or using the wet vac after a leak or flood event, the shop vac stays in the shop.

My grandmother bought that exact model from the door-to-door salesman because "I know Kirby is a good brand". She paid nearly $1000 for it. The salesman initially priced it at nearly $2000.

The foot switch on the back that engages the power assist broke off like 2 years later. She can't use the thing herself because it's too heavy. The hose system is a pain. The carpet shampoo attachment is a laughable gimmick. It will burn through the belt in seconds if you let it stand up on its own without raising the brush height adjustment. The overall build quality is just okay, frankly.

If we ignore the part that literally fell off with normal use, it's not a bad vacuum. But holy shit, even at the "half price" my grandmother paid for it, it's wildly overpriced. If you bought that thing anywhere near the two grand they were asking for it initially, you got scammed.

I've got two of these vacuums, and I like them.

One is some 70s model I inherited from a dead aunt, no one else wanted it, the only problem was a bunch of thread and hair wrapped around the spindle.
The other is a 90s model I got from a thrift shop, with all attachements, for $50. But someone had stripped the hole where the 'head camlock' bolt goes, so there was no way to tighten down the head.
Funky little bolt, I took a bunch of measurements and an M10x1 was a good fit. Fine pitch because the aluminum casting was maybe 3mm thick, and I already had that tap (bicycle rear derailer hanger). Looks janky, works fine.

I don't think I would like them as much, if I was always having to switch the head/hose attachment. And it's not really reasonable to suggest everyone "buy two".

>>2504840
i'm an arborist by profession.
Even modern high quality chains break from time to time. either from misuse, accident or material fault. on average a chain snaps on me every one to two years. luckily modern chainsaws have a chain catcher under the clutch so even when a chain should snap it will immediately arrest on the catcher as it leaves the bar on the underside and be stopped at the catcher immediately - if you are lucky - just dropping down from the catcher harmlessly or slapping the hand guard on the rear grip where it will lose its momentum.
in the worst of cases one of the chain links will get caught and the rest of the chain will come whipping around on the underside of the bar - miss the hand guard and slap the underside of your rear arm, upper leg or your hip if you are holding the saw sideways.
in any case its going to be like a 35mph whip with teeth but it wont keep running and actually be pulled through your flesh as it hits you. wounds from this should be superficial due to the chain loosing most of its energy on the catch.

should you ever pick up a saw with this safety feature missing or damaged, do not use it!

>>2504794
Grandpa once made a circular table saw. Solid steel, the table itself is at least 1 cm thick, height is adjustable but usually somewhere above waistline. Comes with a planer as well, circa 40 cm wide, adjustable depth. Come think of it idk how much power it draws but it hooks up to a triple-phase 380v and once you're sawing everyone within at least 1 km and outdoors knows. It definitely weighs over 200 kg and putting it indoors for after having been used it usually takes two to push&pull it up a ramp made just for it.

Anyway, over the years he's lost a total of 4 finger phalanges to it. I think there were 3 accidents total and a part of a finger was once put back on but not sure anymore, gotta ask some time. It's still his most prized possession and he worries that we will sell it when he passes but I honestly intend to have it moved to my place, mostly for the planer, at least until I learn how to use the saw safely.

>>2523430
>There's a higher chance of error over an entire career than someone who makes two cuts.
You are conflating opportunity with probability...the opportunity to run your hand through a saw or vice versa exists each time you use one...that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable, but the opportunity to use that tool *without* an accident exists each time you use it as well. The total number of uses doesn't change that.
>>2523437
>Turns out when you do the same thing over and over as a career, you get complacent and overconfident.
Maybe you do, but witnessing the repercussions of bad decisions and truly unforseeable mishaps like tool and material flaws creating instantaneous danger and havoc makes lots of people far more cautious and methodical in their work, and far less likely to succumb to ridicule or pressure from higher ups to cut corners.
>And it also turns out that when you do something for a job, you get tend to get tired and your mind wanders.
Again, speak for yourself...if anything people with lots of experience know better when to take breaks or stop when fatigued, and understand better than anyone how to stay focused and why it's important.
You're just pulling stuff out of your ass to support your personal biases and assuming that correlation equals causation when it comes to experience and industrial accidents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523532
>that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable
yes that is literally how statistics work, if you have a p chance of not cutting your finger off and n number of opportunities to cut your finger off then the probability that in your life you cut your finger off is p^n. This function approaches 0 and for a sufficiently large n always ends with you cutting your finger off. Having a larger number of times where you don't cut a finger off is not going to undo the one time it does happen.

Good Morning /diy/ers!

I have come from the Dra/g/on Maid Board to ask about glow-in-the-dark paint.

I have a Writing Computer.
>Writing Computer
https://www.clockworkpi.com/devterm

I like her a lot but she doesn't have a backlit keyboard. I would like to make the whole Writing Computer glow in the dark as brightly as possible so I can operate the keyboard in the dark.

Is there some kind of clear coating or paint which can be used to achieve this?

What is the best technique for bright glowing that lasts a long time?

Thank you /diy/ers for reading my post.

I was at one point considering sticker blasting it with Tohru and Ilulu stickers, but glow in the dark computer coating sounds more practical.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519695
I don't believe you will get a satisfactory result by coating the entire device in luminescent material. The substance would be radiating light over top of the printed surfaces. This is a much different effect than shining a light on a reflective surface. It would be more akin to the glare of light on a monitor, where-in the monitor is trying to emit light, but the surface of the screen is reflecting light in front of the monitor's light. It would wash out the printed letters on the keyboard and make them unreadable.
Perhaps that is okay, if you are a touch-typist and not trying to read the keyboard. But if that were the case, why would you be asking for a lighting solution? The keyboard appears to already have the usual tactile markers for hand placement.
But I think you'd get a much better effect by just detail painting in the accents you need lighted, like the printed letters on each key.

Furthermore, luminescent materials are not "free energy." They do require something to power them.
Some do retain the charge imparted by exposure to UV light and release it gradually after being removed, but the effect of relying on the very limited energy capacity of the coating will likely be underwhelming.
There are radio-luminescent materials like tritium paint. You will pay accordingly for the quality, but these do last several years.
But, ultimately the most DIY feasible solution is just to apply phosphorescent paint that reacts to UV light, and then use a UV light to illuminate it. You will obviously need to power the UV light source, but this is not a difficult DIY problem to solve. You could just put a headlamp on for the purpose.

Actually, why NOT just wear a fucking headlamp, perhaps with a red filter to be less offensive in the dark? Better than fucking about with paint and shit.

posts.name: Anonymous

There are two tribes nearby, one speaks Guarani and I was told they were originally from Paraguay, I met two of them and they were really native, I have never seen anything like that, legit red skin, not regular bronze, red. The other tribe seemed chill, like, like a regular village but everyone looked native.
>>2530899
>How are you getting clean water?
I got 5 20l gallons and went to the local gym for showers. I'm starting with a manual pump + clay water filter (I've been told it's a Brazilian thing, I thought they were everywhere?), should be enough as a temporary solution, but I'm looking into digging a proper well later. I can also get from the river, but I'll need better filters.
>Do you need power?
I have a power line that goes straight to the property, but I need to replace the utility pole, right now I'm ok with no power because I'm only using gasoline tools on the exterior, but I'm going to need it soon, it's going to cost me $285 for everything electrical.
>Do you plan on doing agriculture?
Yes. I'm starting with bees and an orchard since it takes longer to start producing, there are already three jackfruit trees, and some plums, but only by June I expect to start producing for profit. After I start making money that I'll start thinking about growing my own food.
>What's the local community like? Do you worry about security?
The people were very nice to me, I was kind of a celebrity there, lots of Portuguese, Italians, Polish and Japanese, they all seem very racist, kept warning me about quilombolas (blacks). Customer service is great there, cars stop for you to cross the street, people leave their bikes unattended everywhere. Criminality is pretty unheard of there. The two towns near my place have 5k people each, there's one further away with 20k but it was also really safe. I'm not really worried about security, I have a gun and a dog, but I'm also getting motion sensor lights, cameras and other stuff like that later.

>>2516819
Then apply at an electrical company for an apprenticeship. Apply at a few of them. Commercial would be best because that's what most of the code book is. Then either industrial or service work. Service, you'll learn repair and more about electricity in general. Residential new construction is a fast paced game where only the fastest person is fast and everyone else is slow, every job is bid under every other residential company because Fuck quality workmanship, only a few chapters in the code book are needed for the job , so you won't learn much. I started out in residential, because of my father getting me a job and doing side work since I was 12 or so, and trying to learn the code with out ever seeing a transformer, main distribution panel, running conduit and shit like that, it was hard to understand what all the codes were even talking about. Got my journeyman, quit residential and went commercial. Then 2008 happened and commercial shut down in my area. Had to go back to residential and work for a dipshit, who I think sucked a LOT of dicks to get where he was at. That pissed me off enough to get my contractors and start my own company. I do high end remodel now. Have to use my brain troubleshooting and planning and I enjoy that. The only drawback is attic work occasionally.

Figure out how high you want to go and get a job in that field. Figure out what you like doing as well. Industrial is different than commercial is different than residential. A lot of guys are just happy with a paycheck and don't mind running conduit and pulling circuits forever. Some want to move up to foreman. Some, can't do the job and they get stuck roughing in walls and devicing out.

>>2523747
Doug would of course claim that that pic just shows how needlessly complicated a typical bermuda rigged boat is and that junks are superior on that count alone but a) that's not a typical bermuda rig even for something intended for singlehanding and doesn't *need* that many lines led aft...and b) junk running rigging isn't necessarily simple, especially when set up for singlehanded operation.
Picrel is the boat of the guy who did more to advance singlehanded offshore sailing and junk rig adaptation to modern/western hull forms than anyone, just as an example of what a proper setup looks like.
He was a legendary yachtsman and pioneer in offshore sailing techology and junk rigging who proved his ideas with multiple blue water passages, I doubt that Doug would even recognize his name if he heard it.
Also worth noting that after that boat was proven seaworthy and safe in a number of Atlantic crossings, it sank on an Atlantic crossing-

"Jester competed in the first OSTAR Transatlantic race in 1960, which was won by Sir Francis Chichester in Gypsy Moth II . Jester came second. She competed in every single subsequent OSTAR, but in 1989 was seriously damaged under sail and lost."
http://www.collars.co.uk/uk_galaxy/info/1/masts_and_spars/6/the_famous_modified_folkboat_jester

>mizzen
Why even have a mizzen mast?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531128
Split rigs in general allow smaller, easier to handle sails for
any given sail area, which is why they're popular for cruising boats.
Two masted schooners tend to be less naturally balanced (lots of power generated way aft) and harder to control and three masted versions can help balance the sail area out.
Marconi ketches and yawls can be made better balanced than a sloop with a mizzen and allow more sail combinations like jib and mizzen for low power in high winds or a adding mizzen staysail for more power and in light winds.
They can also allow sail/ rig configurations that take advantage of certain loopholes in racing rules, and some yawls are basically just sloops with a mizzen added for some advantage, while ketches are usually designed and masts positioned to use all the masts in normal conditions and may not sail or bslance well without the mizzen.
It's even possible to use the mizzen sheet and a bungee cord to make a ketch or yawl self steer.
In Seekers case much of this will not apply because the mizzen is pretty small and that pilothouse and bulwarks is a massive amount of windage.

Thats a pretty vague descriptor; personally the ones that make my eye start to twitch are when people take quality materials and apply them to garbage structures in ways that render them useless even for recycling.
Extreme deterioration can be repaired, good architecture that's been butchered or otherwise defiled can be restored, but something like exquisitely turned exotic hardwood balusters or flooring or amazing natural stone that's been hacked up to go into some tract house shitbox in a failed attempt to make it appear "grand" and "luxurious" is usually not worth the effort to try reclaiming it.
In my experience Persians are some of the worst offenders and will projectile vomit money and precious materials all over the lowliest and most structurally questionable houses, and then when the 24×24 exotic imported marble quarry tile flooring cracks because the cheap ass stucco tract house they put it in is sliding down the hill and they call you to "fix it", they act like you are trying to scam them by suggesting a real repair and not just doing a cosmetic bandaid.

>>2531044
You can replace existing outlets with GFCI outlets. You can't replace a switch with one unless you run a neutral.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2531044
What anon said. If there’s already an outlet there, you will be cool. An outlet needs 2 wires for power, the live and neutral, and any outlet you will replace has those 2 going to it. But a switch only has one wire coming in, the live. The neutral is connected straight to the light or whatever like anon’s pic. You only have part of the circuit going through the switch, so you can’t just replace a switch with an outlet without getting the neutral wire to it.

posts.com:
For many people and projects, they are a poor source of lumber.
However, they are not useless.

The GOOD - They are often free for the taking and they are often hardwoods

The BAD –
Their size limits their usefulness.
They are often aged or damaged.
They are more awkward to haul home than a stack of boards.
They require disassembly.
They do not all use the same sized boards, you have to find matching pallets to get a bunch of boards that are all the same dimensions.
They sometimes are treated with Methyl Bromide, which is a health risk.
They have nail holes, often quite noticeable.
Sometimes they have unknown substances spilled on them from leaks.
It is a hassle to make them not look like pallet wood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallets are stamped, but not on every board.
Only some pallets have risky chemicals, many are plain wood.

Pallets stamped HT are heat treated and safe to burn.
Pallets marked MB contain Methyl Bromide and should NOT be burned.

>Methyl bromide is a fumigant used to control pests in agriculture and shipping. Methyl bromide also depletes the ozone layer. Therefore, along with other countries, the United States has phased out production and consumption of methyl bromide with important exceptions for critical uses as well as quarantine and pre-shipment.
https://www.epa.gov/ods-phaseout/methyl-bromide

Is there a safe way to get these carcinogens out/off of the wood? Not to my knowledge.

Easy rule of thumb if they are MB or you don’t know for sure.

Don't Burn Them!
Keep the sawdust out of your lungs and off of your skin. This applies to all sawdust, actually.
Don't make cutting boards or other things that touch food.
Paint will seal them if you are still worried about excessive contact.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Using pallets intact has some applications, especially if you can find them the same size. I have seen furniture, animal pens. and greenhouses made from them. (The furniture is usually pretty ugly.)

MB-treated boards make decent outdoor planter boxes and other rustic things like shelves for your shipping container shed to store imitation crab meat.

Taking it apart isn't hard if you have the right tools.

If you are going to salvage a whole bunch of pallets, consider getting a specialized prybar. I would prefer to get one locally, so I could try it out to see if it is worthwhile, then be able to return it easily if it is crap.
https://www.1001pallets.com/top-7-best-pallet-buster-pallet-breaker-reviews/

https://www.99pallets.com/pallet-projects/diy-storage-shed-from-pallets/

This is unlikely to become a Sticky, so please help it stay on the board by posting pics of your projects and links to pallet idea websites that might inspire others.

posts.com:
Pallet Parts and Terminology

Annular Ring Nails (also called Ring Shank) – These are one of the most common types of fasteners used in pallet design. In essence, it is a nail with circular ring threads on the shank.

Banding Groove – Dunnage with a groove cut into the length of the lumber. It is used to protect unit loads from damage when banding is tightened down to secure a load onto a pallet.

Blocks – A square or rectangular piece of wood that is placed between the pallet decks or beneath the top deck. Some blocks can even be cylindrical. Generally, blocks are located at each corner of a pallet, centered on each of the four sides, and in the middle of each pallet. Placement is crucial to ensure block pallet strength.

Block Pallet – A type of pallet that uses blocks to form its base instead of stringers.

Bottom Deck – The deck boards on the bottom of a pallet that are sitting on the ground or floor.

Butted Deck Board – The name given to an inner deck board that is attached to an adjacent deck board during assembly to help strengthen it. These are often used when recycling pallets and pallet parts.

CAD – Stands for Computer Aided Design and helps pallet designers design packaging solutions.

Chamfered Deck Boards – Deck boards with the edges beveled. They are usually only beveled on one or two faces, and allow pallet jack wheels to enter the pallet more easily.

Collar – A wooden container or bin that turns a pallet into a box.

Container Bin Pallet – This is basically a crate, box, container, or four-sided structure mounted on a pallet base.

Deck – The boards or panels that make up the top or bottom surface of a pallet.

Deck Board – The component boards or panels that make up a deck.

Deck Board Spacing – The distance between deck boards on a deck.

Deck Board Span – The distance between the deck board supports. Could refer to the distance between stringers or blocks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Deck Mat – The assembled deck boards and stringers that make up the deck of a block pallet.

Deflection – The amount of bending or deformation in a pallet under load. Could refer to the whole pallet or a specific pallet part.

Double Face Pallet – A pallet built with both top and bottom decks.

Economic Life (of a pallet) – The number of trips a pallet is expected to make in its serviceable lifetime, provided that it remains properly repaired.

EURO Pallet – Block pallets built to European Pallet Association specifications. They usually have a branded logo on them.

Fastener – A component used to join pallet parts together, such as nails, screws, bolts, or staples.

Flush Pallet – A pallet where the deck boards are even or flush, with the stringers or blocks along the sides of the pallet.

Fork Entry – The opening between decks and beneath the top deck of a pallet where forklift forks can be inserted to lift the pallet and load. Sometimes stringers will have notches in them to allow for fork entry.

Four-Way Block Pallet – A block pallet that has openings on all four sides of the pallet to admit pallet jack entry.

Four-Way Stringer Pallet – A stringer pallet that has notches cut in the stringers to allow for pallet jack entry.

GMA or Grocery Manufacturers of America – Thee GMA has its own specific pallet requirements for its standard pallets.

Hardwood – The type of wood that comes from deciduous trees. Generally, these are the trees with leaves instead of needles, but there are exceptions. Although called hardwood, that doesn’t necessarily mean that it’s hard or dense. It depends on the species of tree the wood comes from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Inner Deck Board – Any deck board that is positioned between the end deck boards.

Joint – The point at which the components of a pallet intersect or connect. They are often identified as the end joint, center joint, and corner joint.

Length – In general, this is the first dimension given to describe a pallet and refers to the stringer or stringer board length. For example, a standard 48” x 40” pallet length is 48”, and is also the length of the pallet’s stringer.

Line Load – When the weight of a unit load is concentrated in a narrow area across the full length or width of a pallet.

Load Bearing Surface – The area of a pallet in contact with and supporting the weight of the unit load.

Multiple Use Pallet – A pallet designed to be used for several trips with different unit loads.

Non-Reversible Pallet – Describes a pallet where the bottom deck boards are configured differently from the top deck boards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Notch – A cutout in the wood of a pallet part. It could refer to something like the notch in banding groove, or the notch in a notched stringer.

Notched Stringer – On a pallet, this is a stringer that has notches cut out of it to allow entry for forklift tines. The notch is usually ½” to 1” in depth and 9” long, depending on the size of the pallet.

Opening Height – This refers to the vertical distance between decks on a pallet. It’s measured from the floor to the top of the stringer notch, or from the floor to the underside of the top deck.

Overhang – The distance that the pallet deck extends past the outer edge of the stringer or stringer board. It’s also called a wing or lip. Overhang can also refer to the distance that a unit load extends beyond the pallet deck.

Pallet Life – The length of time that a pallet remains useful. It’s usually expressed in the number of one-way trips that the pallet is expected to make or in units of time.

Panel Deck Pallet – A pallet constructed with some type of paneling product (OSB, composite, etc.) for the top deck.

PDS – Stands for Pallet Design System and is a computer aided design program that helps engineers to design pallets to safely carry a load and maximize the supply chain.

Recycled Pallet – A previously used pallet that is recycled and has been repaired for reuse with replacement pallet parts as needed. It’s also referred to as a refurbished or reconditioned pallet.

Remanufactured Pallet – A pallet that’s been built from reclaimed pallet parts. Sometimes they are also built from a combination of new and reclaimed pallet parts.

Skid – A pallet with no bottom deck that rests on the stringers. It’s a little like a sled on rails.

Slave Pallet – A support base for a palletized load in rack-storage facilities or production systems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Softwood – Softwood comes from evergreen trees. Generally, they have needles instead of leaves, but there are exceptions. The term softwood does not necessarily mean that the wood is a soft wood.

Solid Deck Pallet – Refers to a pallet that is constructed with no spacing between deck boards.

Span – The distance between block supports, stringer boards, or stringers.

Stevedore Pallet – Designed for seaport shipping docks, this pallet is designed with heavy-duty, double-wings.

Strapping – Flat, thin bands that are used to secure a load to a pallet. Often used with banding groove.

Strap Slot (also called a Banding Notch) – The notch or cutout on the bottom edge of the top deck board or the top edge of a stringer. It allows for strapping or banding to tie down a unit load.

Stringer – A solid or notched piece of lumber that is used to support the deck components on a pallet. Stringers run perpendicular to the deck components and there is usually one on each side of the pallet and one in the center.

Stringer Board – Refers to the solid boards that extend the full length of a block pallet and run perpendicular to the deck boards. Stringer boards are placed between the deck and the blocks.

SYP – Stands for Southern Yellow Pine, and it’s the wood most often used in wood protective packaging.

Take-It-Or-Leave-It Pallet – Refers to a pallet with fixed cleats on the top deck that provide a location for forklift tines to get under the unit load and lift the load off of the pallet.

Top Cap – A panel that is placed on top of unit load to protect it from strapping.

Two-Way Entry Pallet – A stringer pallet that does not have any notched stringers. Forklift tines can only enter the pallet on the ends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Unit Load – The palletized goods sitting on a pallet.

Wing Pallet – A pallet with the top and bottom deck boards extending past the edge of the stringers. Can also be a double-wing pallet if both sides extend past the edge of the stringers. Wing pallets can be single wing or double wing.

>>2527963
>The GOOD - They are often free for the taking and they are often hardwoods
Warehouse guy here. Most of the pallets we get are the absolute cheapest, lowest grade of wood possible. Hardwood pallets are prized and don't get thrown out unless they are super fucked up.
>The BAD –
>Their size limits their usefulness.
Same with people.
>They are often aged or damaged.
If they're being given away they are wrecked.
>They are more awkward to haul home than a stack of boards.
Don't bother unless you're going to break them down on-site or have a pickup/van
>They require disassembly.
No disassemble! Johnny 5 ALIVE
>They do not all use the same sized boards, you have to find matching pallets to get a bunch of boards that are all the same dimensions.
Good luck finding matching pallets. You've just gotta accept that your project will look "rustic".
>They sometimes are treated with Methyl Bromide, which is a health risk.
They're usually stamped "MB" so you know to avoid them.
>They have nail holes, often quite noticeable.
Nail holes, chunks of wood missing, split boards, giant staples, screws, etc etc
>Sometimes they have unknown substances spilled on them from leaks.
So don't take the stained ones.
>It is a hassle to make them not look like pallet wood.
Why even bother? If you want it to look nice use nice wood. As I said, if you use pallet wood you should accept that it's gonna look rough.

Pallet wood is a great free source of wood for your shitty backyard fire pit. Lay them down and fill in the gaps with more pallet wood to make a raised floor in your workshop. You can make fun projects like garden stakes, wooden swords, or Old West grave markers with them.

>>2530328
The secret is that those wood pilings are submerged all the time. Without any oxygen able to get to the wood they last perfectly well for decades.
Other examples are the pilings houses stand on in the Netherlands or those supporting the Speicherstadt in Hamburg Germany.

For wood pilings it is vital that they're submerged all the time. The oxygen starvation prevents or heavily delays the decomposition processes.

Best example is now in the Netherlands those same wood pilings. Due to the heavy dewatering of the low laying areas for pasture the soil itself drops down exposing the pilings themselves at the top causing them to rot right under the brick walls.

You're gonna have to get your shit together and actually study the theory, so that you actually understand what's going on both in principle and in practice.
> i'm not interested in theory, except to the extent that i need to understand it in order to do the practical things i want to do with chemistry
You will absolutely blow yourself up, because that specific position that you're talking about is the most dangerous one. If you're a noob retard, you'll just make a kinda unsightly but mostly harmless mess. If you're knowledgeable and experienced, everything goes well. But only knowing the procedures and nothing else is the sweet spot for accidents, because you're knowledgeable enough to reach the point where you have a genuinely dangerous product, but have no clue what to do with it or how to deal with it if shit goes sideways. That point where "you kinda got the hang of it but don't know the theory" is exactly the point where most amateur chemists lose eardrums, eyeballs and fingers.
Not to mention that chemistry is one of those fields where things like to do a flip and fuck themselves up out of nowhere if you let them, and it's gonna happen because of some of the dumbest, most far fetched shit that you forgot to think of.
>things that are hard to acquire on the free market
>for personal enjoyment, not really for profit
Yea I doubt you're making dyes or wood glues. Whatever you're making either goes in a syringe or in a metal tube, and both can kill you very easily, so get to studying.

Excellent book to read is Organic Chemistry by Clayden. Once you cover some theory, try to reproduce it. Make sure to look up associated chemical hazards.

I learned in a University setting (have chem degree), so learning hands on lab skills solo is probably a little difficult. Once you know what you are doing, you can handle basic things safely, but it can be easy to seriously hurt/kill yourself. I would start doing basic lab techniques with very benign chemicals to get the practice down. Not sure of the best way to dispose of organics for an at home chemist

>>2528561
Those are both pretty basic reactions/procedures. I think I did both of those in my first year as well. Chemistry is a very complicated subject and lab techniques can get quite advanced. Typically chemistry courses have a theory and lab component that run simultaneously, so you apply whatever it is you are currently learning. Those two examples would be something done in an intro to organic chemistry course. Upper year courses you can deal with things like more advanced purification, air sensitive reactions (Schlenk line, glove box, etc), pyrophorics, many types of spectroscopy (UV VIS, NMR, IR, etc), chiral specificity, etc. There are a lot of branches to cover, though there is quite a bit of crossover between lab techniques

Caffeine extraction is a basic lab technique/concept (liquid liquid extraction based on solvency, and purification through recrystallization) and gets you using basic glassware (separatory funnel, flasks,maybe a rotovap, hotplate, scale). Nylon is a cool looking but simple demo showing polymerization. You literally just put two liquids in a beaker then pull some tongs through it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
you can ghettoize some things but there are others you will need, otherwise you can only get so far. You need ventilation, either by fume hood, backyard, etc. You need a hotplate to control precise temperatures for reactions as well as a means to accurate observe the temp. You need glassware, obviously. You need solvents, for organic/inorganic separations. You definitely need a digital scale (the more accurate the better, but you can get by with chink/aliexpress type pocket/food scales). You need utensils like stirrers, small powder spoons, etc. You need de-ionized water (distilled water in most stores). You definitely need graduated cylinders to measure fluid volumes.

you can get clever and get pretty far, but you can only get so far before you need very expensive machines to analyze the structure of and verify the identity of compounds.

>>2527930
>Honestly chemistry isn’t that dangerous
I mean...it's not, but the problem is that it can easily go into dangerous territory if you're not careful and if you don't know what you're doing.
>>2528560
>with regard to the dangers, is it not enough to just study well the exact synthesis i want to perform?
No, because if you only study that one synthesis, you don't know what other synthesis might be taking place if, due to lack of knowledge, or due to contaminants in the reactants, or due to some other imperfection, it goes sideways somewhere along the way. For example, you might, say, use the wrong vessel for performing the experiment, and have the reactant react with the vessel too. Or you might not be able to keep the reaction at the required temperature (maybe it's exothermic, and you poured too much, which sped up the reaction significantly, or some random contaminant acts as a catalyst, etc), and thus have it turn into something else while it's outside of the correct temperature range. What then?
Not to mention that things are never perfect. You will never only work with analytical grade reactants, perfectly clean glassware, perfectly linear heating and have perfectly fitted seals. There will always be a degree of uncertainty and imperfection which will eventually sway the reaction in a different direction. And if you don't have the theoretical base and the experience needed to anticipate the direction in which that reaction will be swayed, and therefore correct it before it happens, it can and will go very badly.

my thought is anything complicated (needing to maintain a constant temperature for a reaction, anything involving dexterity, managing gases, etc. would be very hard for me) i'd research beforehand. "what happens if i mix substance A and substance B and the reaction takes place at too low/high of a temperature?" it requires a lot of foresight and there is definitely the chance that something unanticipated comes up. but that's how i've always preferred to learn anything. get as far as i can with as little info as possible, and then learn more info as i need it. has worked well for me for a variety of topics, included ones relevant to my health

Start by playing around with acids, bases, and transition metals. Common stuff like vinegar, baking soda, iron, and copper. Expand from there into other metals, alkalis, and halogens. Next, make little forays into organic chem based on earlier experiments; soaps are a good place to start. From there work on whatever you like, researching along the way. Take it slow and try to figure out what could go wrong before it happens (it will happen). Try not to blind/gas/poison yourself. Ez pz.

My problem: I’ve got an inherited platinum ring my wife wants to cannibalize for the diamonds (as it’s in pretty awful shape), and with me being the fiscally and emotionally stingy individual I am, I’m looking to re-cast the resultant scrap into a band for myself. Issue is, it looks like it was “repaired” some years ago—someone gold-soldered it in two or three places. As a result, the jeweler I brought it to essentially told me it’s unsalvageable. Obviously gold solder has various other impurities, but I’m skeptical of his assessment; surely there’s got to be a way to alloy these and maintain structural viability. Anybody have any ideas as for going about this? And if so, should I go to somebody other than a jeweler for this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477769
I would get a pair of hardened wire strippers and cut out the part that has Au in it. Use wirestrippers to break the diamonds out of the ring and make sure you dont loose the pieces.

You will need an induction furnace and a crucible, check what you can use (zirconia, alumina, and graphite are common). Heat the metal in the crucible then pour it into a thin wire. Work the wire into the shape you want then heat to melt accordingly.

checkin in. pardon the trip but I think it'll be useful. I had a good evening the other day with my king-of-random blast furnace. I melted aluminum over lump charcoal with a hairdryer in a silicon-graphite crucible. I made 2 ingots one run, and two more the next. I attempted a carbothermal reduction of ferrous oxide in a cermaic crucible I bought for $1 at goodwill, and another attempt in a glass crucible from goodwill. The ceramic crucible cracked, and the glass crucible melted, but didn't crack, but I didn't get a reduction. I cooked some pork chops and I beat on a railroad spike for a while until I ran out of charcoal. It was all really retarded and a lot of fun. I did it for like 6 hours. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882
Induction doesn't require material to be magnetic, just conductive. Energy transfer is more efficient when magnetic, but steel will become non-magnetic when sufficiently heated. If anything you would prefer a non-magnetic, non conductive crucible such that the metal is directly heated rather than indirectly through walls of crucible. Big challenge in getting up to temperature is all of the heat losses due to radiation and convection. For cast iron / cast steel graphite-based crucibles are most commonly used. Not straight graphite but don't know the exact formulation.

>>2478010

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882

Oh, it's you. You need to learn thermodynamics. The steel furnaces are lined with ceramic liners (usually some cementatious clay). This + the steel's ability to be cooled by air is enough to avoid melting.

Whe the clay liner fails you get all the molten metal shooting out the hole in the now-melted steel.

The lid and liner are very thick relqtovely speaking; this insulates the melt inside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2488793
Most of the iridium on Earth (probably) ended up bonded to iron and is still molten beneath the crust, which is the reason there is so little accessible to us.
We do mine it, it does occur naturally, it's just rare stuff.
There's more of it in meteorites than in the layers of Earth we have access to, that's not unusual, that's true of numerous elements.
This makes it useful as one of the indicators of large meteorite impacts, one of many valid and observed indicators.
That's about it. It's useful stuff, been produced and used commercially for just shy of 200 years now.
It's just uncommon in the top layers of the Earth's crust where we can access it.

In the scale of the universe, it's an element with a fairly high atomic number (77), so it's going to be relatively uncommon compared to "most" elements with lower atomic numbers. This isn't a perfect rule, but it's a decent rule of thumb.
The reasons why are complex, you'd be wanting to read up on cosmic nucleosynthesis to get an idea of how various elements were formed by the Big Bang, exploding stars, merging stars, cosmic rays, all kinds of neat stuff. Isotopes and stability play a big role in this, certain elements don't have known stable isotopes, and are so "unlikely" to exist in nature they may well not exist anywhere in the universe they aren't actively being produced by an intelligence with the intention of producing them, like we do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2490205

The most viable iridium deposits on Earth are massive, fuck-off huge ancient impact craters from around the time the crust was forming an stabilizing. those are actually a big part of the reason Africa has so much mineral wealth in general. Outside of that, you find a some in old volcanic complexes that have eroded away.

You can pull "native" iridium from copper and platinum refining in minuscule amounts, or in very rare igneous deposits as microscopic bare nuggets alloyed with other metals. There's a couple iron-iridium minerals and one copper-iridium mineral that forms naturally as inclusions in deposits of other platinum and iron-group minerals, but they're vanishingly small - 5 - 10 micron in diameter, and very very sparse.

Basically, the tiny amount that we currently produce is all produced "accidentally" as a byproduct of refining other rare metals. most of the viable sources occur as a "side product" of mining gold conglomerates in Africa and gold sands in North America.

it's a damn shame, as iridium complexes might end up being some of the most compelling phosphors and catalysts ever discovered, but no one in their right mind is ever going to suggest large scale industrialization of an iridium-based chemistry. Even metallurgical uses are basically all luxury items at this point, with some very low volume extreme-condition industrial uses.

>>2496976
The power requirements are MASSIVE. Always used for small batch metallurgy or low melting temp metals that need VERY carefully controlled temperature profiles. Large batch Induction heaters are almost always used as reheaters or preheaters these days. Arc heating or gas fired is still preferred.

Induction smelters are great for fine control and quick batching but are more expensive than any other heat source.

>>2499296
Heat red hot. Oil quench with pliers no swishing (firing tip down). Heat at AT LEAST 500°F (more like 600 if you can) until it shows a good darkening yellow color.

That should give you a proper hardened profile with enough tempering to not explode.

Google search (O1 tool steel tempering graph) and aim for 50-55HRC if you want more info.

>>2508422
Easy recipe: take some generic 1020 or 4140 or something (a proper quenchable tool steel if you are brave) and cut it into small chunks (or buy some steel shot if lazy). Take some cast iron powder. Pack the chunks VERY WELL and tightly into a crucible and seal it or at least borax the shit out of the top. Bring to half way between the melting temperature of the cast iron and of the steel.

The cast iron melts and diffuses into the steel. Eventually the chemistry of the steel and castiron average out until it is a mass of solid chunks and intermingled semi-solid mushy not-quite-cast iron. Consistency of a concrete that is a little too dry. You need to only heat it long enough to get this diffusion about half way - if it becomes 100% solid you went too long. Allow this to slowly cool so that everything diffuses well together but maintains a distinct pattern.

The steel you used is mostly the original steel (now higher carbon) but is all bound with a web of very carbidic pearlite, carbides, and other high-Si intermetallics.

Anything that is carbide forming (tool steels, bearing steels) resists carbon diffusion through martensite (huge Ni/Cr atoms + small Mn/V atoms fug up the diffusion) so you can develop a decorative oxide layer but maintain strength and hardness.

Acid reacts with and rapidly corrodes the surface of metal. Can be used in combination with a resist to make some sort of pattern or just applied generally to expose virgin metal, as for weld testing.
You can get both sulfuric and hydrochloric acid from a well stocked hardware store. Sulfuric is sold as drain cleaner, and HCL is sold for cleaning concrete and masonry labeled as muriatic acid. Even the acetic acid in cleaning vinegar will work, albeit more slowly. Copper sulfate, which is sold for horticulture and aquaculture can also be used for etching, but I'm not sure of the specifics of the process.

With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. I found a 3D printing filament "Mold-Lay" that is low temp enough to be melted out in the kitchen oven, but still makes a smoky mess and more expensive than PLA. I usually use 50% sand 50% plaster. The 45 minute plaster works better than the 15 minute plaster (and is cheaper too). Use a paint brush to paint the mixture on the surface before fully submerging to make sure it fills all the nooks and crannies. Using 356 aluminum rather than potluck aluminum will give much better results (found someone on Ebay selling for $3/lb).

>>2521382
Instead of just putting a model in plaster and burning it out you make a multi-layered shell of porous ceramic glaze and essentially sand. You then can preheat the entire mold after burnout and fill with metal then let slow cool in the furnace.

The finer the model (wax is historically used for ease of burn out, modern SLA works great but takes longer to burn) the better the end product.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
Not sure if it's any use but I have a bit of experience. You shouldn't be seeing blue with just the fuel on, you also don't have to make a huge acetylene flame before lighting the oxy, I'd say once the flame has volume and is putting out thick black smoke then you're good for the oxy. When you're tuning the flame people talk about a neutral flame but it's kinda hard for a beginner to grasp what that means, basically you watch the little flame needle (or needles depending on your nozzle) sticking out the hole (or holes) in the nozzle tip, you want that needle to be as long as possible without the flame flickering or changing color, the base of the flame should be blue with the yellow and orange further out, if you try to make the needles too long the flame will become a bright white and jet out of the nozzle in a sort of thin beam so that's a good way to tell you that you went too far. Sometimes gauges are weird so I can't really help you there, used to have a gauge at the shop that would correctly read the oxygen psi at the pressures we needed but the needle would never drop below 20 psi even when we turned it off. Make sure you have a welding/brazing tip and use good filler, keep the filler shielded by the outer flame not the the inner needle and don't dip that needle into the puddle, that's pretty much it for mild steel, it's kinda like tig when you start going.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
>>inb4 don't weld with it

Whoever told you that was a moron. The little torches are great for sheet metal and light work. OA was the only way to weld aircraft parts before TIG was invented in WWII.

Get a copy of the Oxwelders Handbook, no later than 1939 which was peak OA welding era. They're about ten bucks online.

This forum is one of the last with quality OA welding and related equipment posts. It's noob friendly. https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/2-MIG-TIG-Stick-And-Oxy-Fuel-Welding/

Blacksmithanons will also enjoy this place: https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/121-Sticky-Forum

A shade 5 face shield is most comfy. Goggles are shit. Your local welding supply has them. Sunglasses also work well but I wear glasses and prefer shields which protect the face.

Determine what make/model torch you have. I buy tips via Ebay and only use US-made torches. Torches are typically cheap and I've got several from the 1930s I pressure tested (with clean compressed air) that sealed perfectly. Ivory soap is fine leak detector and recommended in old factory literature.

Don't sweat the gauge so long as you don't run too high a psi which for OA welding there is no need anyway.

PSI info and some background:
https://forum.millerwelds.com/forum/welding-discussions/7731-pressure-regulator-setting-for-o-a-cutting-and-welding

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529282
TP4056 is linear regulator which means it turns the energy into heat. If you have 5V USB supply with 1A, the battery will need 3.7V which means you need to burn one third of power, which means at full power the chip will get hot.
https://www.ame.cz/TP4056-TP4056ES-LN4056-H-_a261147_10699.pdf

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/32402397769.html

I used this to revive dead nokia phone with too low battery by hooking the TP4056 module directly to plus and minus terminal when I had no charger at hand with the nokia jack.
Nokia is a small phone, you will need to look up the battery pins and appropriate datasheet to make a hack mimicking termistor and maybe the battery status indicator pin with some resistor dividers to hold these pins at appropriate voltage levels.

Instead of the TP4056, you can power a bigger device with this provided you fool the battery pins into correct levels if you setup the output to be 3.7V as the lithium battery is.
It is a switching buck/boost module with nice voltage display, fairly easy to set up.
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000138918802.html

This is all without bypassing the battery controller which is the simplest solution.

I bought one of these several years ago based on the certainty I would eventually need it. I accumulate BBQ jugs because only one cylinder means when that one runs out you will have downtime which of course is not acceptable.

https://www.sportsmansguide.com/product/index/mr-heater-forced-air-propane-heater-60000-btu?a=1835683

Storm froze one water line feeding my water heater despite it being insulated so I aimed propane heater at that section of wall (the line is outside the house and will remain that way for maintenance convenience) and thawed the line. You can use forced air heaters in many ways by deflecting the air to your target. These are handy as fuck and likely in stock even during storm conditions. The blower can be powered off an inverter connected to your car or truck if grid shuts down or of course by a generator.

I take lessons learned notes after every serious weather incident then correct any problems since it's reasonable to expect shit will happen again.

Tip for anything LP, buy a bag of hose connector O-rings online and tape it to your heater or other device so you never lose it. In other news I don't buy toilet paper by the sheet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507298
Well, they're like other heat engines in that to get more power out, you have to raise the compression. The big advantage internal combustion engines have is that they run at high compression "for free" - a comparable Stirling needs to be pumped up to pressure before running or be a sealed pressurized design. There's nothing stopping you from building one that uses higher compression other than the engineering involved.
Swedish submarines (Gotland class) use Stirling engines instead of diesels, so they're not just toys.
I could be wrong, haven't looked at the subject in a few years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509786
There were lots of small improvements made in the 1930s and 1940s when they were more widely used. Unfortunately it seems like most of the knowledge is spread out among communities that don't talk to each other.
For example, there are a few people in Sweden who drive gasifier-fueled cars, and every single one of them use a "stacked pancakes" fabric filter (a large "sock" that is tied off around wireframe discs; used to be canvas cloth in the 1940s, nowadays it's fibreglass). I've never seen for example Americans use fabric filters. Burgers all seem to use the Wayne Keith design, but the details are a trade secret and nobody outside of the US has heard of it.
The basics should be the same though, and there are some obvious things like insulating the hearth (firebox?) and using a heat exchanger for the air intake that I would do.
Another thing would be to convert a modern electric hybrid car. The pros and cons of a gasifier and a battery vehicle means they would complement each other pretty well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516500
Cyclones filter out particles; they are heavier than the gas and get flung to the outer wall and fall down. The intended use is that they catch most of what comes out so that the filters clog up less often.
Dealing with tar is mostly done, from what I've seen, by minimizing production (right fuel, right temperature) and cooling the gas before it reaches the engine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517210
>What do you mean by efficiency here?
Power vs. fuel consumption

>having a cold gas at the start of the cycle increases the difference in temperature and therefore pressure.
Having a colder temperature would increase the efficiency of the Carnot cycle if delta T remains constant. However, delta T is purely a function of the amount of fuel burnt, heat capacity, and heat lost to the surroundings. A slower burn is going to lose more heat to the surroundings and an incomplete burn means less fuel burnt. In practice, a slower burn is also going to have less room to expand, and less work will be recovered from it, but a Carnot engine doesn't have any notion of a stroke or expansion ratio.

>>2504527
I wonder how hard it would be to make methanol from wood or coal syngas. You can convert gasoline engines to methanol rather easily.

There's a 99.8% selective methanol synthesis from carbon monoxide and hydrogen with a copper and zinc oxides catalyst at engine cylinder pressures (750~1500 PSI) and kitchen oven temperatures (250C / 500F). It can also work with carbon dioxide and hydrogen or carbon monoxide and water, since CO2 and H2O are intermediates in the process.

Apart from methanol being a gasoline substitute, there's also a simple dehydration reaction with solid acid catalysts (such as gamma alumina) at the same temperature and pressure conditions to produce dimethyl ether. DME has very similar handling characteristics to propane, and is non-toxic and non-corrosive and can be burned for heating and cooking, but also works well in diesel engines (with some conversion required, obviously).

These processes seem like they should be simple enough for small factories run by an individual or small team. Not too much harder than the combination of wood gas conversions and moonshining, and you get fuels that can be handled, stored, sold, and generally used for all the same things as today's standard fuels. You can make them from fire wood in the countryside, coal in coal country, and if solar panels keep getting cheaper, eventually from electrolysis hydrogen and CO2 from chemical capture methods or biomass (you can still get CO2 out of biomass you can't easily burn properly for energy).
