>>2518526
>Can we get a description of what's happening here?
Sure. I guess I should add some reference number. Essentially there are 3 circuits:
- the air circuit (hatched) that cools the mantle before being diluted with exhaust and then is fed into the reactor (bottom right)
- the wood gas circuit from the reactor going through tar absorbers and filter before going to the gas turbine, while being cooled by water
- the water circuit that goes in opposite direction to the wood gas circuit, picking up heat throughout the path, before being superheated in the spiral at the bottom of the reactor and then powers a steam turbine.

Lots of details (condencer, recuperator, waste extraction etc) are missing but I hope those are obvious anyway.
Wood in the first tar absorber is fed to the reactor through the yellow square chute at intervals, thus recycling the tar.

posts.com: I wonder if maybe my old furnace water heater might be producing small amounts of wood gas. It's an old combination oil-wood furnace, I'm running it on wood this winter. Basically I just pile it full of logs and ignite, it pipes the smoke through a chamber that heats water, which goes into the radiators and taps in my house. It has an old-fashioned thermostat hooked up to the air intake, so that as the water approaches a set temperature it will feed less air to the fire, and thus not boil the water and also keep the fire going. If I fill it with wood in the evening it'll still be smoldering in the morning. However, if I open it before it has had time to burn through all the wood and it's been at minimal air supply for a while, it'll immediately shoot a fireball out of the fuel hatch. A few seconds later I can tell fresh air has reached the embers because that's when the wood leaps into flame. Could the initial fireball be from wood gas produced by these logs lying on top of glowing embers but not getting enough air to actually burn for hours on end, or is it some other phenomenon?

Airlocks aren't that complicated, you just need two doors.

>put fuel in loading chamber
>close outer door
>open inner door

Using wood pellets is dumb. It would probably just waste fuel idling/cruising with a gasifier. Just use an engine-driven chipper with a conical pulley to change the speed and adjust the flow of fuel into the engine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523152
The amount of energy it would require to run a wood chipper off your engine would almost certainly negate any advantage you'd get out of the setup. I think the most efficient way to to this would be to somehow automate or at least greatly simplify the process of loading entire logs into the combustion chamber.

As for wood pellets, a lot of the reason for their efficiency advantages don't apply in a gasifier. They're more efficient than a regular wood stove because they burn using a forced convection system, and as a result of the forced convection and their high density they burn at a much higher temperature than regular wood. Forced convection isn't possible in a gasifier and the heat of the reaction doesn't matter much when the process you're using relies on further chemical reactions downstream of the gasifier.

I also question if charcoal in a gasifier is a good idea. The process of making charcoal is essentially the same thing as what's happening in a gasifier, except by separating those processes you'd be losing out on the stream of volatile exhaust gases that come out of the charcoal and relying solely on the carbon monoxide to fuel your car. Using charcoal you're throwing away a good portion of the energy of the wood, and once again the advantage of a higher temperature burn doesn't benefit a gasifier like it would in a furnace.

>>2524004
Here in Sweden we explicitly used normal firewood. The government set standards saying that only specially treated birch was acceptable for cars (called bilved, "car firewood"), but in my parts of the country (very rural, even today if you don't work in forestry or paper manufacturing, you're a farmer) people were just using the exact same firewood they stockpiled for heat in winter, and by all accounts it worked just fine. Some of the wood gas converted cars stayed like that for decades, until the government got stricter about what you were allowed to drive on the road. Even when I was growing up in the 90s my neighbor still had an old wood-gas tractor. He never used it because he also had a modern diesel tractor, but it still ran. He drove it into town for the autumn market festival to show it off a few times. Using firewood probably produces more exhaust or ash than the bilved, because pine doesn't burn as well as birch in the first place, but I don't think that matters too much. Pine firewood is significantly cheaper than birch, let alone birch put through whatever treatment the government wanted people to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524467
Here in Norway, Alder was the preferred kind of firewood for wood gas generators. Birch is a bit of a cliche and has less energy per kg than many other kinds of wood, but has the advantage of burning quietly without sparking. That is important when using open fire, but less so when using wood gas generators. Pine and connifer have a lot of resin that can cause tiny explosions that throw sparks everywhere, but is perfectly find in a closed oven.

Other than drying, I have no idea what kind of treatment they had for birch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530812
I think I understand what you meant now.
Filtering takes place in several steps. The first one (above the gas generator) catches tar and some particles in the tar. Once the wood in the tar absorber is fully loaded, it is sent down the chute (yellow square) into the gas generator. The filter is rotated so right side wood is turned to the left side and more wood is added. This lock means you avoid CO poisoning.
The next filter is more tar filtering by wood chips, as shown in >>2504529. You could move that to the gas generator too.

The third filter is teh cyclone filter. And I guess you are concerned about carbon rich particles removed here. I would expect most of this to be ash particles rather than carbon rich particles. I don't know how you can separate these. Just feeding it all bak into the gasifier means you will have a lot of ash circulating.

posts.name: Turbro
posts.com:
>>2530831
Well your design is certainly more efficient than mine if paired with an Otto or Diesel engine. It could perhaps be simpler, lighter, and even more efficient if the engine was the detonating Quasiturbine type and the steam engine were replaced with pre-heated air. The EGR is potentially interesting if you are using the 2 CO2 + heat -> 2 CO + O2 reaction to feed + cool the gasifier, and provide some suction at the exhaust. However, the biggest downfall is what to do with the carbon particles (especially if you are feeding in pressurized exhaust).

Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529721
colorfabb, prusament, and polymaker
In that order.
Colorfabb has a 0.003mm tolerance and makes the most colors
Prusament has a 0.002mm tolerance but you're stuck when it comes to colors and the extra tolerance doesn't change anything and you're paying more.
Polymaker has a tolerance of 0.003-0.004mm tolerance.
All of them strive for 99.878% purity.
Everything else will clog your printer as the priory on purity drops to 84% with sunlu etc.

I simply use fusion360

Step 1 Import your STL. In Fusion 360 click on File -> Open. ...
Step 2 Converting to BRep. Right click on the mesh object you just opened and select Mesh to BRep. ...
Step 3 Cleaning up the model. Go to surface in the top menu and look for merge in the modify menu. ...
Step 4 Scale back the object. ...
Step 5 Enjoy your work.

>>2529577
Not him but,
Reduces ghosting and artifacts. By like a lot. Most people print on bed springs, I use hard spacers. I use mesh bed leveling to handle all that stuff. I use linear rods instead of v-slot. And I use a full enclosure. You can also print 30-40% faster with dht high flow nozzles. Anyone who tells you otherwise needs to stop 3d printing. Ldo has very nice motors but they're expensive. Closed loop systems work as well. It's a matter of control. If you want to know more, please join the voron discord server. Watch this video.
https://youtu.be/uQh1aNwr4Aw

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530051
I believe vibration is not caused by weight distribution changes in bedslinger printers, its the sudden change in momentum by the bed, in your pic it would be apparent when the "bed + carriage" part suddenly stops moving and start accelerating the to the opposite direction to print a U turn or something.
A simple counterweight would do nothing against this effect, you would need to time it precisely and move it the exact way the printer moves, essentially having a second printer upside down.

at this point get a core xy or put a big mass under the bedslinger and tighten everything you can on the printer

In Solidworks, import an

You have to just eyeball some things like hole centers, but it generally works good enough CNC plastic poo extrusion.

Which one did you get? I have an Ender 3 V2, and it's great. I'd recommend upgrading it with a Bondtech LGX extruder and a Phaetus Dragonfly BMS hotend. The Bondtech LGX uses the same connector as the default extruder stepper motor, but the connections are different, so you'll have to manually rearrange the pins on the connector. The Phaetus Dragonfly BMS requires an adaptor to install, which you can 3D print with a strong, temperature-resistant filament like Nylon. (You'll need an enclosure to print with strong, high-temperature filaments like Nylon, which you can get for $50.)
https://www.reddit.com/r/ender3v2/comments/pufbsh/bondtech_lgx_with_ender_3v2_installation_notes/
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08FFHSP9M
It looks like Amazon is currently out of the small ones, but I'm sure a medium sized one would work, and it only costs a few more dollars.

>Didn't have it every level.
Before I even printed anything, I installed the Creality CR Touch, along with silicone replacements for the bed springs and a thermal insulator for the underside of the bed.
https://www.ebay.com/itm/334410084502
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08BZ689TW
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07W1Y5J8D
I'd also recommend upgrading the firmware to the latest version of JyersUI.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o1zXYwgIPLY
I'd recommend getting the 5x5 version of the firmware after you install the Creality CR Touch. After you complete an autoleveling cycle, view the bed map, and make manual adjustments to the bed based on what you see. Eventually, you will get a bed that is level within a single tenth of a millimeter on all points of the bed. Based on which version of the motherboard you have, you're either going to want to download E3V2-BLTouch-5x5-HS-v4.2.2-v2.0.1.bin or E3V2-BLTouch-5x5-HS-v4.2.7-v2.0.1.bin.
https://github.com/jyers/marlin/releases

Downside is the resin is a bit smelly and clean up sucks -- if you get one be sure to stock up on paper towels and nitrile gloves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530660
>I feel that having the plastic ever so slightly soft when layering on a new layer of PLA/ABS could help with adhesion between layers and in the overall strength
Yes, but layer time is a big factor here, and so is nozzle temp. It's multiple parameters combining to affect multiple performance attributes.

>baking in sand or salt be a far better alternative to part hardening/tempering.
Baking does nothing to improve layer adhesion until you actually re-melt the plastic. The purpose of baking while buried is generally to minimize warping from the change in microstructure associated with annealing. Given the existence of things like Volcano PLA that anneal in open air without distortion, IMO there's little or no practical point in that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530967
Sounds like the extruder isn't doing its job.
Check and see if the extruder gear is trying to turn. If not, the stepper motor is likely the issue. Check and make sure the wiring is all properly connected and nothing wiggled loose. If it is turning but not pushing the filament, there might be flakes of filament on the extruder, but those can also come from the filament scraping the lever arm if it's feeding in at a sharp angle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530976
>>2530967
Oh, and if it's a stock plastic extrusion clip/lever arm, those tend to crack and stop working after a few months. If it does, the bearing that presses the filament to the extrusion gear might not be able to do its job, so the gear will spin and just push the filament away rather than feed it forward through the bowden tube.

If your extrusion gear is turning but not gripping the filament, pull the filament out and take the extrusion clip/lever arm off and check for cracks.

You'll have to use the Preheat PLA/ABS command in the menu to remove the filament, and you should probably preheat anyhow because the Move Axis -> Extruder command you want to use to test the extrusion gear won't run if the printer detects that the nozzle isn't heated enough for filament to flow.

So, your steps:
>Prepare -> Preheat PLA (or ABS if you're using that)
>Wait for nozzle to reach 180+°C
>Use Prepare -> Move Axis -> Extruder to try to push and pull a few millimeters of filament
>Watch the extrusion gear, bearing, and filament closely
>Is the bearing holding the filament against the extrusion gear firmly?
>Is the extrusion gear turning?

>If the bearing is not holding the filament against the extrusion gear, do this:
>Hold down extrusion clip and quickly remove filament (Taking care not to release it, lest the spool decompress. Either tuck the filament into a hole on the spool or use tape or a clip to hold the filament down.)
>Unscrew the extrusion clip carefully, setting the pieces aside in a safe location
>Examine the clip for cracks or breaks
>If you find any, you need a new clip. Full metal extruder kits are cheap and widely available for Ender 3s

>If the bearing is tightly pressed against the filament but the gear isn't turning:
>Check and see if the shaft is turning but the gear is not
>If so, see if there are any grub screws to tighten on the gear
>If neither the shaft nor the gear are turning, the motor isn't running
>If so, check wiring

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2530998
>>2531001
Glad you got it worked out.
Wiring should be the first thing you check but as you can tell from how long it took me to get around to mentioning it, it often gets overlooked.

I usually recommend waiting until the last moment to make upgrades, but with stuff like the plastic extrusion clip on the Ender 3, it's a matter of "when" it breaks, not "if" it breaks, so ordering a kit and having it nearby for when the clip cracks in 6 weeks, 6 months, or a year from now may be wise.

Personally, after being forced to wait on parts to make repairs to my Ender 3 several times, I now have a toolbox with spare bolts, washers, hotends, stepper motors, extruder kits, wiring harnesses, and keep the original mainboard and build plate in case the replacements ever fail me. The only failures now that can force me to wait for a delivery are the power supply and the frame.

A note on upgrades: If your Ender 3 makes a lot of noise while printing, I can't recommend an upgrade to a 4.2.7 board enough. It provides a noise reduction of over 90% compared to the noisy boards. The fans become the loudest thing on the printer. The board upgrade is the difference between having to run the printer in another room vs being able to run it on your desk next to your computer comfortably.

>>PLA slowly deforms at 70-80°C bed temps
>huh?
I use a bed handle with a raspberry pi camera mount ever since switching to a tempered glass build plate.

I printed the handle out of PLA. It worked fine at 60°C bed temps, but when I increased temps to 70°C and then 80°C in an attempt to prevent prints from lifting off the bed during printing, the parts of the handle closest to the bed slowly soften and the entire handle starts to sag down under its own weight.

It connects to the printer with the leveling screw posts. I haven't checked yet to see if I can attach it by placing it beneath the springs/silicon spacers instead of right up under the build plate, but I feel like that might also screw with your leveling every time you pushed and pulled on the handle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531069
much above the glass transition temperature of a material significantly softens it. increasing temps to 70C or 80C will soften it and it will deform under its own weight.
i print high temp PLA at 60C. i don't see any reason to go above that. you can print PLA on an unheated bed. your adhesion problems are best resolved some other way, not by cranking the bed temperature.

>>2531084
Speaking from experience: It can help, but it depends on how and where the bed is warped.
For example, I had a warp that raised part of the bed diagonally from just to the right of the back-left corner to just below the center of the bed. Using the default 9-point bed leveling, the probe mostly missed the fact that there was a ~0.5+mm "hill" running across part of my bed.

25-point leveling might do better, but I just switched to a tempered glass bed instead. You need clips to hold it on an Ender 3 and something to scrape the prints off the bed since you can't bed it to release prints, but it's mostly been a worthwhile upgrade. I only developed adhesion problems like 40 hours into printing on it.

posts.com: I'm making a model that I'll give someone to print. What should I know to make a printable model?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531120
nothing is theoretically unprintable so long as the resolution is high enough. you can always use supports. but there are best practices. think about how the thing would print on the bed. if you're printing each layer at .2mm thickness, then you obviously cannot make an accurate feature only .1mm tall. limiting overhang angles, designing in tolerances (how much depends on the type of printer and the axis), not modeling unsupported structures.

avoid requiring the user to print supports. they waste material and leave poor surface finish. realize that unsupported overhangs/bridges will always look like shit on the bottom. avoid them if possible.

What about tolerances? Do I need to make slots slightly bigger or smaller? Does plastic shrink or expand while printed?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531139
PLA does shrink slightly on cooling but it's more a concern of not perfectly accurate movements. if a toolpath starts or ends on an inner wall of a slot, there will be a glob associated with that movement and the final part will not mate without being sanded or filed or reamed or whatever. make them a little bigger.
i can usually get by with clearances 0.1mm larger than needed (4 thou).
you could send demo parts to check fitment and see what tolerances you can get away with.

>>2531412
other anon is retarded. ideally you would have manual control to tram your surface. rigid springs are fine for this. maybe bolts would be better because they'd be more rigid. ideally you could get a perfectly manually leveled bed and not have to rely on mesh leveling at all.
the reason is because mesh leveling necessarily puts artifacts into your print. with a mesh, your z steppers will slightly raise or lower the gantry to compensate for the non-leveled bed. great. however, if this continued all the way up your print, you'd have a top surface as warped as your bed. so, gradually the magnitude of the z stepper compensation fades out over the first 10 or so layers. once high enough up, the z stepper quits doing little movements to compensate for the bed and only steps up for the next layer.
this is "fine" for slightly warped bed, and not fine for a very warped bed. because it will put artifacts in your print, because of the fading of the Z steps. do you get what i am saying?
that's why you'd ideally be able to level the bed manually, then use a mesh to handle the minor warping. relying on the mesh is fine if your bed is trammed well naturally, but you're fucked if it's not. having the control to manually level is a good thing.

>>2531428
use the right hand rule. X is thumb, Y is index, Z is middle.
the print head ought to home to the origin. 0,0,0.
so, orient the graph so the origin is where the print head homes to, and now you know how the mesh corresponds to the actual bed.
to confirm, make a prediction as to what would happen if you spun one of the wheels. then spin the wheel. then check the mesh.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526257
>Surely there's some homeowners here?
No, we're an 80/20 mix of mom's basement shitposters and schizo park-bench dwellers.

> Is there a way I could remove the spars running through the middle of the roof space and reinforce the beams they support to give me an open attic, or am I stuck with them?
Is that your attic in the pic? If so, why fucking bother with such a short space?
But in a lot of wood framed gabled attics, the ceiling joists form a system which prevent the walls from spreading out horizontally due to snow or gravity loads pushing down on the triangle of the roof... There's also commonly "rafter ties" (googe image search it) which are the horizontal members visible in your pic. Rafter ties act in tension to keep the rafters from vertically being pulled up off of the ridge during a wind event. You can often replace them by using ridge straps instead (galvanized metal straps that fasten the upper ends of each pair of rafters together over or across the ridge)

If you have roof trusses up there, then odds are that NO you can't just cut the members out in the middle lol. Or you could with either reckless abandon or some idea of the engineering involved.

>Also what are some good ways to try and keep my roof space cool during summer?
White roof surface helps a lot apparently. Adequate venting will help too but it's harder to do if you're trying to convert an already built and inadequately vented attic space into a conditioned space.
Just adding more insulation to the attic floor will probably help more than using a ventilation fan would.

There's also a system where you run a pipe along the ridge on top of the roof and spritz some water on the roof surface to provide evaporative cooling. Apparently this can often keep your attic 40F cooler while using ~20 gallons a day.

>>2526257
To remove those ties, you would need to replace the ridge (the board running along the peak that the top of all the rafters attach to) with a stronger ridge beam capable of supporting the roof load from end to end. And each end of that ridge beam would need to have a post supporting it down to the foundation. If you give me the two dimensions I can tell you what size that beam needs to be.

Another large concern, perhaps even more of a concern than the roof, would be is the existing ceiling platform capable of supporting the required floor load for a living area? I'd bet that it's not, and that board that's running perpendicular to the ceiling joists is a mid-span support that was used because otherwise the joists would be spanning too large a distance even just for a ceiling/attic load with no living area on top of it. What size and spacing are those ceiling joists, and how long is the span? It would likely be the same as dimension B for the roof above.

posts.com:
What you are holding there is the cladding from an uranium fuel rod, most likely a souvenir from a decommissioned nuclear reactor. They are usually encased in a shielded container and only taken out for educational purposes, with appropriate protection, as they can still be quite "hot" for decades after removal.

Uranium is twice as dense a lead, that's why it is so incredibly heavy.

For proof, here's me holding one that has been decontaminated and is well intact.

Yours appears to be slightly darker in color and shows a significant amount of wear, which indicates that the chromium coating (the shiny finish) has started to erode over time.

This is not good, and you really do not want to hold that with your bare hands.

See that conchoidal fracture? That, my good sir, is probably elemental silicon. Probably a wafer-stock rod from a chip-manufacturing plant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530159
Artificially aging your tools is pretty cringey. That's the equivalent of "distressed jeans," which is something no decent tradesman owns.
>Exception: hard hats. If you buy a new hard hat, drag it through the sand to take the shine off it. At least where I work, guys will actively harass other guys on site if their hard hats or hi-viz look too new.

You're not asking about this, but CONDITIONING your tools increases their lifespan and is a mark of professionalism. Rusty, splintery, poorly cared for tools are the mark of either a fucktard or a poser and you need to steer clear of them.

To condition your wooden tools, use a plane to take off the varnish and apply linseed oil. If your tool handle is oversized, you can use your plane to give it an octagonal shape which many old trades guys swear by for comfort. Allow it to cure completely, then apply at least one layer of Walrus Brand tool oil, both to the handle and to the steel head of whatever tool it is. If your tool (or PPE) has leather components, use Obenauf's leather oil and conditioner. If the tool is rusted, use steel wool or another abrasive to remove excess rust and restore remaining rust with 30% vinegar. If you're going to paint your tools, use the highest quality enamel paint you can get your hands on and follow the instructions else it will not last. Should your tool have moving internal parts, the manufacturer likely recommends specific products to lubricate with, and there are many different kinds of lubrication and grease that vary in their intended use (temperature/climate, use severity, etc).

So why am I telling you about restoring and conditioning your tools if you're interested in being a poser? Because you'll have tools that look like someone cares for them, even if nobody's using them for their intended purpose, and that will make them "more characterful" than any amount of fake patina or artificial aging could ever achieve.

>>2527236
Depends on what you can change.
>Renting
You're fucked, landlords problem
>Buying
Replace old insulation with either foam closed cell or rock wool, new windows, new doors, weather seal doors and windows, caulk along exterior siding base to prevent drafts, check draft gates in external vents, insulate attic by piling up rock wool or blow in
>building
Use 2x6 studs for exterior walls, fill with spray foam close cell or rock wool. On exterior of house, add another layer of foam board insulation between OSB and siding. 3 pane windows standard, all external doors should be filled fiberglass (not steel).
for added fun: Orient your house so that the front door is facing south in the northern hemisphere, or north in the southern hemisphere. paint the front door black, and install steel awnings over every window. In the winter, the sun will be low on the horizon and hit the black door, transferring heat inside. In the summer, the high-noon sun will be blocked by the steel awning and the door/windows will remain cool. If you're going to do this, use a steel exterior door instead of fiberglass. My front door is basically a space heater in the winter because of this principle. If you can't face the front of the house towards the winter sun, face the back and make the back door have the same principle.
Also: Make sure your attic is vented in the summer with a blower to prevent it from heating the house, but the vents can be closed/turned off in the winter to allow the sun to keep the space above warm. Attics might sound nice as storage but what's better is as much insulation as you can layer up there, I'm talking 24-36 inches thick over everything. fuck it.

The key is to basically pack in as much insulation as possible and eliminate air leaks, while at the same time increasing the thermal mass of your house to prevent wildly fluctuating temperatures.

posts.com: Your main issue would be the variance of energy transfer throughout. Meaning to get to a said energy you'd maybe need a heater, electric of course, go above normal temperature. Keeping that energy in would mean lots of insulation. Energy doesn't like to stay in one place and you risk CO or CO2 poisoning with a very sealed room. Your best bet is a Stirling engine which also produces energy from a alternator, to a powerbank. Have a pad or thermal conductor touching inside the house, and the opposite end of the piston on the outside. Does need set up and engineering, but boy does it do the job. Do the math first for power needed to get to temp, how to have x% air flow and what your loss of heat would be. Trust me, suffocation is an issue. Then run your models for how big of a power bank you'll need and leave a 30% variance of extra power just in case. Also be hooked to the grid if you can help it. If not just use ice or something. Look at what materials are most dense and theres your insulation.

>>2528835
>SOURCE NEEDED
As an example, to get an HVAC license in my state you must:
- have five years experience in HVAC
- be approved by the state licensing board and pass a background check BEFORE you can even take the license exam
- pass the license exam (which requires you to take classes beforehand since it's impossible to pass if you take it cold)
- show proof of $500k liability insurance
- to keep your license you have to renew every year, but to renew you have to show proof that you completed at least 8 hours of continuing education in the HVAC field.

Fun fact: in addition to the State license, you are required to get a license from each city you plan to work in. You can't pull permits or get inspections without one, and you can't get a city licenses without showing them your state license. In addition many cities require you to post a bond to get a city license. In my city alone you must put up a $25k bond.

Then there's truck insurance, liability insurance, business licenses, unemployment fees, worker's comp. and an endless fuckery of taxes.

posts.com:
The real scam is that while most specific trade licenses require actual experience in that trade and test for competency, in many places general contractors can legally perform work that have zero qualifications for as long as the overall scope of the job meets the statutory requirements-

"A general building contractor may take a prime contract or a subcontract for a framing or carpentry project. However, a general building contractor shall not take a prime contract for any project involving trades other than framing or carpentry ***unless*** the prime contract requires at least two unrelated building trades or crafts other than framing or carpentry, or unless the general building contractor holds the appropriate license classification or subcontracts with an appropriately licensed specialty contractor to perform the work"
So if a GC contracts to build a room addition or a garage that involves carpentry + two trades like painting and a roof, he can do it all himself along with earthwork, concrete, tile, drywall, paving, cabinets, glazing, floor coverings, landscaping, etc. or he can hire a dude in the HD parking lot to do the work under his GC license and it's all legal.
Which doesn't really bother me since he accepts the risk too, but it sucks that people who have specific trade licenses who have shit tons of real world experience both in that trade and possibly others get treated as inferior to the king shit licensed general contractor who may have almost no skills or practical building experience in work he takes on, and gets tested on how to write contracts and other paper pushing.
Almost every licensed trade guy I've ever known was skilled and conscientious and took pride in their work, while the biggest know-nothing scam artists who didn't give a shit and did terrible work were general contractors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529082
When you're in the hardware store picking up parts, definitely get a multimeter. It's a very useful device for a DIYer. If you're on a budget, Harbor Freight or the equivalent will have one cheap which should last you long enough.

I mentioned the voltage b/c the switch does a very simple thing. If the pressure in the tank falls below a set point, it closes the contacts you have circled in the original picture. Those contacts literally connect the black to black and white to white wires coming in and out of each conduit. One set comes from your breaker panel, and the other goes to your pump. That's it - contacts close, pump gets power, pump fills up pressure tank, contacts open, pump stops getting power.

if you measure the voltage coming from the panel (one black and one white) with your multimeter you'll get either ~120 or 240v. Most likely 240 unless you have some small pump.

you then want to check that the wires going to the pump are getting the same voltage when the contacts are closed.

Hope that makes sense - not trying to talk down to you, I'm just not sure how much of the basics you have down.

If you are getting the same voltage on both sets of wires, your pump is getting the right voltage, and unfortunately your pump may be busted (at that point, get a well/plumber guy to come out and do some more testing)

If you're getting zero voltage on the pump side, the switch is not connecting them. This is where i said do lightly sand/file the contacts down as sometimes they get fouled and won't close correctly. Hell, one time i had a silverfish get stuck in the contacts and i didn't have water for half a day due to a literal bug!

And if for some strange reason you have 240 coming out of the wall, but pump is getting less, switch is likely broken in another way and should be replaced.

Watch a few pump/switch/tank How To videos. They taught me a lot when i first moved to a house with a well.

This is an extremely simple system and it is well within the reach of even a novice DIYer to attempt to repair it.

>>2530445
OK, your readings are just showing that you have voltage coming into the switch from the supply, but it's not making it to the output. In other words, the switch isn't closing.
If there is no pressure in the system, then the switch contacts should be closed. Look at the switch's mechanism and see if you can find what's wrong.

Usually with these kinds of setups, if you want to find out if the switch is the problem or if it's further downstream, you can first check for voltage at the pressure switch input, then switch the breaker off and temporarily connect the switch's input and output wires using wirenuts (black to black, white to white, etc).... Switch the breaker back on and you have effectively hotwired your pump, which should cause it to start pumping.

Watch the first 3 minutes of this video, and this guy explains it pretty well.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AmUTNekC9EE

The type of pressure switch that you have is equipped with a reset lever. You have to hold that lever at the right position for a bit so that it will manually close the contacts in the switch, causing the pump to be energized and creating pressure in the system.... once it reaches a preset level, it will be able to sustain itself and you can release the lever.

The basic diagnostic flow with a "no water from my well pump" complaint is to make sure that the pump is receiving power. If it's getting power but it's not pumping, then suspect the pump, it's state of prime(in applicable pumps) or it's control box (for models equipped with a surface mounted control box)
You haven't really established yet whether or not it is properly receiving power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Actual glass fabricator here.
Tempered glass is not the go to material for table top whether in a frame or with floating edges, because it doest like edge damage *at all* and also doesn't like concentrations of heat like you get in typical table uses.
Tempered glass is notorious for shattering with small concentrated point impacts and tables get those all the time from dropped utensils, tableware, etc.
The other thing is that tempering has to be done after any edge profiling is done so doing it risks all that labor. It's also done in an oven and can leave marks where the glass is supported and other imperfections that don't work well with something that needs optical clarity like a display case.

The way you get table capable glass strength is by using thick annealed glass, and 1/4"-5/16" is perfect for that kind of perimiter framed box, but not thinner. 1/2" is adequate for free standing di ner table and desk tops up to about 48" in any dimension and after that it starts to sag under its own weight.

Bottom line is that if a glass table or desk or display case breaks from dropping something on it you dont want everything else on it to dump at once into a pile of glass bits. If you chip an edge with annealed glass you can re-grind it or polish it out or cut a strip off, tempered just explodes.

posts.com:
Im with >>2529692, but there may not be a lot of good used ones around. The Proxxon DESU is a really good drill press in the $400 range but often too small/weak if you work with metal

If you’re okay with chinese: There are two very common generic Chinese designs btw. A smaller one (usually with 350W motor, 5 gears, plastic pulleys and straight slots in the table, around $150 mark) and a bigger one (the one in your pic, often with metal pulleys, removable chuck and X-shaped slot in table, around $250). The designs seem to be well known around manufacturers, many different plants produce it and sell on alibaba in different colors and configurations. But the design is tested and not that bad. Quality is hit and miss, but it’s usually the reseller/brand that does the QA, not the Chinese manufacturer (so more reputable ‘brand’ can mean much better quality even though it’s the same machine). The small one is even sold under Makita’s brand in some regions.
However its press-fit chuck on the small one is a no go, as there’s no way to replace anything except for the belt and those cheap chucks don’t last very long.

As others are saying, it's mostly just using the software (if you are dealing with corrupted data and not physical damage to the drives).
Perhaps a professional has done a bit of study into common file systems and data structures, and therefore has a bit of background knowledge to inform which tools they try and avoid brute force. But you can just brute force it with good tools and patience.

>>2523823
>Funny enough the anon giving him shit ended up making this guy do a better job. You ought to honestly thank the guy who gave you the truth about your gay ring

LOL, that was me and it's thanks enough to see that he took the critique in the spirit in which it was intended and reconsidered where it was at in the process and is happy to have done so.
Just for the record, there's nothing wrong with just making things functional or not perfecting diy skills when problem solving is the goal, but the whole point and function of jewelry is to be aesthetically pleasing to as high a degree as possible, literally something the owner will treasure.
"Good enough" really doesn't apply the way it does with a garage shelf or other utilitarian objects. It's OK to not be a master on your first try; the point is you may still suck on try 35 and the solution in general and for any individual piece is to suck it up and do the work that's missing.
The good news is that that's almost always finishing work so with minimal planning and common sense something that's not that great can be greatly improved, it's just really boring and tedious work which is why people blow it off.
I'm proud of the OP for rising to the challenge and he should take pride in it too, regardless of how it's received as a gift.

>”what’s this fee?!”
>”sir, that’s a disposal fee for your oil.”
>”baaah I just dump mine in the backyard when I do it at home!”

>”what’s this fee?!”

>”baaah you guys are just selling them used somewhere else! I’m taking my tires with me, you aren’t getting your little commission!”
>wanting to beat old man to death because Walmart was NOT giving me any commission especially for some bald ass used tires

Probably hands down the most frustrating experience was when an old woman came in to get four new tires and had some old man in tow who was a “friend” helping her out. He was a complete asshole to me and convinced her I was on commission (what’s with the geezers and commission?) and I was up selling her. What was the exorbitant product I was trying to pawn off on this poor lady? Balancing of new tires.
>IVE NEVER IN MY LIFE GOTTEN MY TIRES BALANCED!!
>…uh, ok sir

Most satisfying exchange I ever had

>closing up shop
>back door to automotive from parking lot locked
>hours clearly stated on door
>fifteen minutes after closing time
>me and coworker cleaning up shop before heading home
>random asshole with young daughter starts pounding on door
>open door, “may I help you sir?”
>”ARE YOU CLOSED?!

>…”WALMART IS CLOSED?!?!”

>slam automotive door
>asshole turns to glare at me through locked door then slinks away

It was absolutely exhilarating to finally tell one of these assholes off. Guy never showed though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mild steels above all else for high strength, low cost, ease of working, ease of welding, ease of repair, and availability. The majority of things are built from mild steels because it just plain works.

Aluminum can get fucked with it's brittle welds, higher cost, lower strength, and being harder to repair. It does have some use cases where it shines.

Wood is for furniture, houses, some buildings.

Concrete for floors, concrete pads, and foundations.

Basically they all have their use cases, but if I could only pick one to work with for the rest of my life I'd choose mild steel.

I had one built, since I don't live in the US, standard construction method is brick

>Copper tube and fittings are the original lead-free piping materials.
Copper water pipes and fittings are standardized in the US, and must be over 99.9% pure
ASTM B111, UNS C12200

>It's well known and long established that copper has antimicrobial properties.
While it cannot and does not sterilize water flowing through it, it reduces the bacterial levels in the water slightly, and prevents the sustained growth of microbial life within the pipes including certain algae and fungi.

>Copper water pipes and fittings are standardized in the US, and must be over 99.9% pure
No plastic in your copper pipes, pretty obvious one there.

>The copper contributed by your pipes to your water is negligible.
Yes, there's copper in your water. The EPA regulates how much copper is allowed to be in your water.
That amount is tiny, because it's actually pretty easy to consume too much copper if the levels are high in your drinking water.
The amount contributed by copper pipes in your home is incredibly, incredibly miniscule.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Before bypassing things, check the basics lad; what voltage exactly is your battery holding at? It can certainly be enough to start a car when brought from a warm place, but if you have any parasitic draw, or just an old battery, all issues with your battery come out in cold conditions. It's worth putting a multimeter on it and seeing your voltage - under 12V is generally not what you want to see. My own car right now starts and drives, but when the weather turned Canadian on me, using the power windows would dim the headlights, for example. It is very much so the little things that will tell you much here.

If she's making $150k a year, you can definitely afford a house. Life style creep is real and hard to deal with. I made 120k while my wife made 35k but now she's making close to 80k and keeps buying more bullshit. Most women are fucking retarded with money.

I use a budget tool, the one I use is You Need A Budget. I religiously tracked every expense and categorized them, and after 6 months I showed my wife what we spend our money on. Every month I sit her down and we go over what we want to budget. We can afford a $2700 mortgage and over $3000 in child care (2 kids now). We almost max out 401k's as well but have up on IRA.

It took some rough uncomfortable talks to get her to calm the fuck down with her money and make her understand that if we pay the mortgage every 2 weeks instead of monthly we will pay it off 7 years early. It took some time to show her how much we needed to save if we want to retire at 60.

You are her partner. Don't belittle yourself for making less. You can look for a higher paying job maybe on the coast where she "works" now. There may also be a tech bust sooner or later. It sucks, but you need to make her understand you're a team, have a discussion about what HER goals are, and help her reach them. If she's spending like this maybe she doesn't care about a house. Get your goals situated and help her come up with a plan.

First off, your post and other anons' posts in this thread are saddening to read. I'm not writing this as a slight against you OP, it's just a bad mentality to have where the value we place on ourselves and our relationships is so dependent on how much money is earned. I get that it's necessary to survive, but it's an unfortunate reality that one is seen as less valuable in dating/working/social contexts because they don't work a stellar job; even if their character is impeccable.

You should also talk with your wife about your finances, how you plan to budget for necessary expenses, etc; but don't talk to her in a patronizing way about it. It's very true that most women aren't that great with money, there's a reason why most marketing targets women and most consumer spending is done by women. You both should have an agreed upon way of how your money is saved and spent, if you're pooling your earnings together. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528994
Biggest issue is that you can’t join the supporting pieces to each other very well so there is little resistance against racking. Take the ikea kallax cabinet for example. You can put 100kg of dead weight on it easily, but as soon as you put something wobbly on it, it falls down because the joints cant resist any kind of moment (and it bends+breaks if weight is not spread evenly). There’s a point where you can keep adding cardboard but it won’t get any stronger unless you reinforce the connections between the pieces.

If you can’t do that, you could fill it with sand, ping pong balls, pvc pipe or even shreds of cardboard, basically anything that must compress to deform the structure but resists compression.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528994
You could make your forms out of mdf which is basically cardboard compressed until it's strong and stable.

Then texturing the thing is an entirely different process. idk that grout is supposed to create an even layer, but you could try it on some scrap. I expect plaster, concrete, and stucco are better mediums for this task. All of these can be dyed to color and have different grits of aggregate to meet your desired texture. They can be troweled or stamped for texture as well.

>>2509382
see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

>>2509676
show examples of how this could be made, 3d printers are definetevly cool, but I noticed a trend where people will simply assume that a printer can print anything. How would you measure out your face this way? I did with simple gypsum bandages. And then print it how? Carbon fibres? For costs, a 33cm x 33cm rectangle plate costs about 15€ in material costs, the groin plate has this size. thats 9 + 9 patches of the heavy a d light glass filament. 1m2 can be cut into 9 patches. 1m2 of glass weave costs about 3-5€, so about 3 for the light and 5 for the heavy, 8€ total for the weave. Epoxy resin can be expensive, cheapest I found was 11€ per kg. for a 33cmx33cm plate with 18 layers of mixed weaves I needed 750g of epoxy, so about 7-9€ or something. Now you got a basic plate for what 15-20€. Porcelain is the best worst ceramic for balistic protection, you can source that for free. Add another glass weave for spalling protection above that to stop porcelain fragments from flying everywhere and boom you got a decent plate I'd say. 25€ max.

>>2511923
the protective gear part is a different beast. the orthopaedic gear is to prevent knee injury from missteps or non optimal posture. same goes for the lumbar belt.
even the cheap aldi versions do their job.

joint injury is the number one eliminator of modern troops.

for the fit: add a padded comfortable belt strap with some semi-rigid plate support. this way you circumvent the spine being loaded and free your lungs more. putting padding on the shin lower side, so it rests better on the shoe, can make the bug a feature.

some light knee pads could help with the armor and hard knuckle or sand gloves would add some necessary hand protection.

for the groin plate: try to cut it int an inverted trapezoid (basicly upside down chest plate shape). then it moves more easily when walking. the two removed pieces can be added as belt flaps/ armor skirt pieces.

>>2513688
For maximum efficiency, cut the fat out and chop it into ~1cm cubes. Put it in a pot with some water to cover and heat it to a simmer. After a few hours all the fatty acids will be rendered out of the tissue, then you sift the chunks out and let the liquids harden. The fat layer separates and floats on the water. To clean it just scrape the grimy bits off the bottom of the solid fat layer and put it back in a pot with fresh water and a generous handful of salt, bring it to a simmer and stir it a bit, let it cool and repeat until pearly white. Finally melt the fat down and insert a wick. There you go, odorless human candle.
Human fat is about 7700kcal/kg which is a lot better than wood pellets which generally sit around 4300kcal/kg. You only need a small fraction of that energy to refine it.

To make soap all you need to do is weigh your human tallow, then bring it to about 50°C. Take 26.82% of your fat weight in distilled water and 13.41% in pure lye and dissolve it in the water (do it with good ventilation or die). It will heat to almost boiling so let the mixture come down to around 50°C also, then dump it in the liquid fat and blend it with an immersion blender until it turns into a sort of paste. Scoop that out into whatever mold you like and let it sit for a day, then demold it and let it air dry for 2-4 weeks.

Why teflon? Why bedliner for bonding? Line X actually is bombproof, mythbusters made a vid about that, discussed this in thread #1 or 2 I think. The company by the same name actually has a specialized type of coating called pax- something. They use that for bombproofing government buildings. But you can't simply buy either of these products in a can. A shame. Only certified paintshops who are in contract with Line - X get that stuff and are allowed to coat projects wih it.

For the teflon, I just don't know what it would acclompish. I've seen a vid where a dude made a pauldron with glass filament + carbon fibre layers. But carbon sucks. Glass fibre cloth is simply the cheapest.

I wrote ZNA productions and techthisoutmeow multiple times, donated to their patreon. Wanted them to build and shoot test panels with my method. Mentioning it again, 9 light + 9 heavy layers and additionally porcelain + another 3 heavy and 3 light ontop. No further responses for about two months or so.

But thankfully a german hansguns offered to test it for me, I'll be sending him 2 such testpanels after xmas. I've gained some doubts of the success of my plates delivering what I hope for, because I did something different. I didn't vacuum press the plates during curing. My theory is, the epoxy itself should stay where it is and not be pressed out excessively. Further, I think a pressed conventional plate has it disadvantages too. The layers are already then pressed together and it' s maybe easier to penetrate them this way.

Only live tests will show if my theoretical method has advantages over singular type of weave pressed plates. If I had something like military interest funding, I'd research this matter more troughly, but I'm a literal neet lmao.

So I actually made a plate like this when I was a teenager. I took a piece of polycarbonate, placed ceramic tiles on top and then laminated the whole thing with many layers of fiberglass and polyester resin. Then I went to a gunfag board and asked some one to shoot it for me.

The results were not good, basically the only thing that didn't penetrate fully was .22LR. I don't remember exactly what he shot it with but I recovered the jacket of a large caliber pistol, possibly 45ACP and a small rifle round, most likely .223. Simply put, ceramic tiles are not hard enough to stop rifle rounds and while they may be able to fragment pistol rounds, they then turn into shrapnel that blows right through the backing. The whole thing was too stiff to work even as 3A armor and while polycarbonate is very tough, it cannot withstand the high impulse of a bullet impact, it basically tore open like a flap and let everything through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2497894
I've been down this road before. Don't do it. Electrical stuff is the absolute worst to try to keep organized, since every type of thing (resistors, caps, connectors, fuses, relays, ICs, sensors, LEDs, the list goes on) has 100 different subtypes, and often each one of those subtypes has a subsubtype. When you start putting shit in tackle boxes, unless you're very careful about how you organize it, you might as well throw it away, because you're never going to see it again.

I've found the best way to avoid clutter and minimize "forgotten items" is to maximize literal visibility of your stuff. Genuinely, taking the doors off of a bunch of my floor-to-ceiling storage cabinets was one of the smartest things I've ever done. Those harbor freight small parts organizers can be a blessing and a curse. If you're going to use one, you need to label each drawer, otherwise it just becomes a garbage container, and you might as well throw it away.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2497889
you're gonna want a multi-layer approach for top hoarding. First you line the walls with peg-board. Then at chest level you're gonna want work-bench tier table/shelving that goes along the sides of the work room. You can then subdivide the lower sections into actual drawers or cubby hole spaces for large containers or tool chests. Now since you didnt finish the cieling you're gonna wanna get some cordage and hang stuff off of it, like baskets full of gloves and shit. We arent done yet, because that ladder in the corner can be used to access the rafters, where you are going to shove all the shit you will never use but dont want to throw away up there. Get some 2x6s and make some light shelves that fit between the rafters. Dont put anything heavy up there though, because realistically the framing of your roof isnt designed to hold weight in that direction but its fine if its just a few hundred pounds. probably.

Garbage collection is privatized the world over, even in the few places where it is still a public service (like it was 300 years ago), it's typically just a publicly-owned company, which is NOT a government organization and is NOT paid by tax dollars.

Everything related to anything you've seen/had to personally do for a patch out of lack of options or no other choice.

Unlike most other stuff, I've actually got fresh OC for this to kick it off and to set the mood. The hot water pipe for my washer burst right at the faucet, with no recourse or ability to repair it due to the fact that it split right on the coupling, and it's christmas day so nothing is open. This wouldn't be a major issue if there wasn't going to be a hard freeze in less than an hour, and I had ran fresh out of end caps. Thankfully, out of everything I can describe about myself, I am at heart (and proud of it) a huge idiot. I didn't have an endcap, but I DID have a handfuls of elbows, t's, and some spare pipe. Behold, the "What the fuck are you smoking" endcap, santa edition. The other repair next to it was where I had tried to repair the pipe that had split before that faucet coupling did hastily, and then the remaining pipe signed off from steam, never to log on again.

Is it dumb? 100%. Does it work? Also 100%. I figure it'll do until stores open tomorrow and I can repair it properly.

The valve is cut out of a bicycle tube with some leftover rubber on the sides, inserted into the extuingisher. The ring screw presses against the washer which also squeezes the sealent ring. Tried without the washer, but that procedure broke my first sealent ring.
>>2526532

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526581
So it's just a rubber bicycle valve stem pushing against the inside of the hole ... and that hole is probably about as "smooth" on the inside as it is on the outside.
Honestly I'm surprised it only leaks as little as it does.

You may want to try using RTV or some kind of gasket-maker on the inside of the hole and around the valve stem before you tighten it up.
But the best way to do this would be to weld a threaded bung onto the tank then thread a valve stem into it with pipe sealant, and not rely on a cut up rubber bicycle tire to hold air.

Based CO2 extinguisher mod^

Instead of adding dip tubes I retain my cylinders as vapor withdrawal units for MIG shielding gas, tire inflation in the field and bead seating and to run an impact in a pinch at high pressure. Fancy version, I just use a regulator/hose/brass pneumatic chuck etc.

https://trail4runner.com/2020/06/21/diy-power-tank-co2-tank-airing-up-tires/

They do serve as extinguishers by inverting them Of course your now-liquid-withdrawal cylinders can be used for vapor withdrawal applications by inverting them.

I also collect other industrial gas cylinders. I use nitrogen for HVAC work ( the first job I did on my truck paid for the tools and I've done several since), I use MIG mix and argon for welding but you can and I have pressure checked HVAC systems with those more expensive gases so no need for nitrogen if you don't do a lot of that stuff. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Early in the previous thread I posted about making a custom edge bander for my chipboard chest-of-drawers-project. On the upside, after some fine-tuning and getting low viscosity EVA glue, I started seeing passable results. On the downside, the passable results still required manual re-gluing with an iron about 70% of the time, maybe down to 50% after I got the hang of the required speed and consistency of feeding. Still, it was a massive pain in the ass to do some 40 meters of edging this way. I also didn't have a very good setup for trimming edges with a router, did a lot of it manually with a chisel. All in all, it probably took like 10+ hours to do the edging, not including the time spent building the edge bander.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2514476
After suffering through all that and finishing the project, I went and bought a chinkshit horizontal edge bander. The vertical one I built might've been passable after some further improvements for small pieces, like the sides of drawers, but it was really hard to handle larger parts, like the top plate. It was also completely impossible to use it for banding thicker than 1mm, even 1mm was difficult. 0.5-0.7mm was alright.
This is what I then bought https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000569137844.html and first tests went well. It's pretty fast, the bond it leaves is really strong as it applies glue on both the ABS strip and the wood, and thanks to all the big rollers you can squeeze the edge on hard, even 2mm strips stuck just fine. Will see how it holds up next time I actually have a larger amount of edges to glue. Also I will definitely build a swiveling router mount for cutting the banding, I've had it with chisels.
The steel frame was an extra layer of complication, if I had to build the same thing again, I'd either go with thinner material or just use chipboard for the whole structure. Also it's really fucking heavy.

I found it in the archive. Whoever made this sticky, thank you. I started woodworking recently to help with another hobby/job and the information has been extremely helpful for me.

Welcome to the woodworking general, here we discuss the working of wood and the tools and techniques of working wood. So far we tend to be mostly hand tool folk with a slant towards cabinetry and carving but all are welcome and we have some capable power tool folk amount our ranks. General carpentry question such as framing/decking/general construction seems to get a better response in the /qtddtot/ or /sqt/.

>essential /wwg/ books
Tage Frid Teaches Woodworking, gives you everything you need and shows you how to do it multiple ways from hand tools to power tools and gives you the knowledge to determine which is best, and then he teaches you how to apply what you learned. The PDF of the second book can be found in the usual places, but the other two are MIA.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561588261

Christopher Schwarz tells you everything you need to know about planes and saws and their use
Handplane Essentials
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440332983
Handsaw Essentials
Best to find this one in PDF from the usual sources, out of print and pricey!

Chris Pye wrote the book on carviing and keeps on writing them.
https://www.chrispye-woodcarving.com/

The eastern tradtion, Japanese Woodworking Tools: Their Tradition, Spirit and Use by Toshio Odate
https://www.amazon.com/dp/0941936465

Leonard Lee The Complete Guide to Sharpeninig, how to sharpen most everything.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561581259

Bob Flexner - Finishing 101, covers the common stuff, his other books cover the uncommon and go into more depth
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440308454/

Illustrated Cabinet Making by Bill Hylton, learn to design furniture that won't fall apart
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1565233697/

>essential /wwg/ tv
https://www.pbs.org/show/woodwrights-shop/
https://www.newyankee.com/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518425
I dont want to come off as a dick, i like the table. just a friendly meant hint
>How do you analyze these things in design?
me? i watch old pieces and restaurateurs on fixing old stuff and of course vintage literature. for lumber furniture there is nothing new under the sun!

Little history lesson.
The sliding dovetail was mainly used as butt joint for carcasses and shelfs racks. relatative quick, really sturdy, no glue, no drying time! and thus dismountable -> nearly all big old furniture was build with that in mind.
"relative" as in quicker than building the carcass out of a million handcut dovetails with a day forced waiting.
The second application often seen even today is as a cross bar for tabletops or stools. it prevents warping and provides a simple way of mounting to the apron, was often done with wooden nails without glue for ease of transportation.

afaik long to long grain same direction as on your table isnt not a historical application. if for example the wood swells in humid summer and without climate control (both board getting wider), the dovetail could come loose.

>>2521248
It is not difficult to do freehand with just a saw. Cut them as well as you can, clamp them down at a perfect 90 with the joints as tight as they can be then run the saw down the gap. You can also pare with a good sharp chisel to get the final fit which is what I prefer for most woods. But it is not that hard to get perfect cuts freehand, just takes some practice with a bit of scrap. People regularly do other sorts of joints and get great fits freehand but for some reason butt joints are believed difficult despite being just one cut. Dovetails in 18" wide boards for casework with their dozens of individual cuts, no problem; butt joint, IMPOSSIBLE!

If you really want a jig for cleaning this sort of work up than the miter jack is the better solution. A hand screw makes an alright improvised miter jack, a little fiddly to get both jaws lined up perfect but not so bad, snug it up and then tap them to perfection with a small hammer or scrap of wood, tighten it up fully then clamp it down and go at it with chisel or plane.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521533
>Even with my Veritas 14 TPI crosscut backsaw
The Veritas is about as poor as it can get for such cuts, excessively thin plate and too much set, generally a finely set rip tooth would be better for this. But you should be able to do it, if the cut is rough that means you are putting to much pressure, the saw is binding slightly or you are wobbling a bit side to side. If the cut is smooth at one or both ends and rough in the middle that means binding or too much pressure (with a plate so thin almost any pressure is too much), if the roughness is even across the length that means you are wobbling.

The trend in making blades as thin as possible is not as great as the marketing makes it out to be, the blade will distort too easily. Find yourself an old back saw from before the thin plate came into vogue, file it rip, put in some set and then stone out almost all of the set and you will get wonderfully smooth miters in hardwoods. Stoning out the set instead of putting in very little set will give just enough fleam (functionally the same as fleam but not really fleam) on the outside of the tooth to give a smooth cut in even many softwoods. The old saws were not thicker because they could not make thin plates, they were thicker because it made it easier to get a smooth cut, the old guys knew what they were doing, sure it cut a tiny bit slower but it meant little to no fine tuning after the cut. Ultimately, such thin plates only benefit you when cutting dovetails, everywhere else it makes things more difficult.

With my old Spear and Jackson or Marples backsaws I can cut wonderfully smooth miters all day long in beech, I can manage it with my LN saws but I have to go slower and it would be a chore with the cross cut carcass saw of theirs I have, blade is too flexible and it is thicker than the Veritas.

>>2521621
We are talking about the same saw. I did not say it was aggressively set, just that it is overset for miters which need little set. Any saw which works well for crosscutting will be overset (but still doable) for miters. It does flex but we are not talking flexing to the point where you see the blade bend or the cut curves, just a slight bend which can only be seen in the marks left by the tool, you can't avoid this and it is a fact of life. You can hear this flexing in many saws, if the blade rings during the cut it is because the blade is flexing fast enough to be vibrating and sound a note, especially noticeable when a saw is getting dull. Back saws generally will not ring like this since only ~50% of the blade can flex and that unflexing portion and the spine prevent the flexing from progressing to vibrating. Grab the toe, wiggle it side to side, see it move.

>>2516049
These sorts of drills are actually designed for steel and do a nice job of it with a quality twist bit. They are not quite as good for wood (and soft/non-ferrous metals) since the bits tend to advance too quickly for the low speed of the drill. For your regular hardwoods you can sharpen you bits as you would for brass or aluminum to give more of a scrapping action and they work quite nice. Standard twist bits work great with these and the really dense woods. They work well enough for soft woods as long as you do not care about a clean hole, brad points help but modern brad points tend to like a higher speed, they are not bad in softwood but fail with these low speeds in hardwoods for the most part.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524205
The way to do it properly is to plow grooves into all 4 pieces and let the board sit unencumbered in all of them, since the board will expand and contract with humidity changes. Traditionally you would then join the pieces with tenons on the short sides and mortises on the long sides. Since the grooves would go all the way to the edge on the long sides you'd make the short side tenons the width of the groove and give them a haunch to cover up the ends.
The cheap way without buying a plow plane, tenon saw and mortise chisel is to buy a used router for $30 and some shitty bit about the width of your board, then make stopped grooves and just butt- or dowel joint the frame.

>>2524293
The point is that increased movement and end grain is not a good thing, nails have very little holding power into end grain. The old carpenter totes and the like were not meant for longevity, They were disposable items knocked together quickly, they were made for carrying the necessary tools to a job site, if the needed tools for a job don't fit well into any of your current totes then knock a new one together. When one starts failing, toss it in the burn barrel and replace it when needed.

That tote has no risk of flexing unless it is filled with lead and only the drawer front is nailed into end grain, which will eventually pull out most likely. Bottom might be nailed into end grain, which is not a good thing. My preferred tote construction is bottom rabbeted into the ends, sides nailed on and flared slightly to help support the bottom. It is how great grandpa taught me, he was a finish carpenter of the old kind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526070
Make a pole barn, they are easier for one person to make, takes less wood, and has a nice free dirt floor.

https://www.milmarpolebuildings.com/pole-barn-terms-explained-part-1/

There are many different terms when it comes to building. Here is the breakdown of the basic terms you will hear when looking into building a pole barn.

On Center (O.C)

On Center is how far apart the lumber is spaced. For example, we space the posts 8 feet from the middle of one post to the middle of the next post.
Gable

Gable is the sides of building where you can see the peak of the roofline going upwards.
Eave

Eave is the sides where gutters are installed for water run-off, where you would install gutters.
Trusses

Trusses are the support system of of the roof and provide the interior ceiling. They are customized to support your pole barn. The centers come in 2, 4, or 8 ft, depending on the ceiling load. Trusses come in many shapes, but mainly these two:

Standard – has a flat bottom which allows for a flat ceiling

Scissor- crossed beams provide a vaulted ceiling. This gives you more head room or space for a loft if extra height is needed.
Overhang

This is how much roof is hanging past the walls on the ends and sides of the building. Overhang will typically be 12 to 24 inches.
Purlins

Purlins are the pieces of lumber on the roof that provide structure and where the metal panels are attached.
Girts

The girts are similar to the purlins in that they are 2x4s placed 24 inches on center, but on the walls instead of the roof. Girts also provide wall support.
Girder

The top support pieces are known as girders. Beam sizes will typically be 2×10 or 2×12.
Bottom Wall Girt- Skirt Board- Splash Board-Grade Board

There are several different names for the piece that sits on ground level. It is treated wood because it is in contact with the ground.

Use 1x2" stock, layout the curve on the 2" side, cut with a coping saw and refine/cliean the curve with sandpaper/rasp/file, repeat. Glue up how ever many needed to get the desired width. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526696
As a side note, I would dump the screw tightening, slow and futzy, I would do a cam. You can make one from wood, just do a search for cam clamp plans, should clue you in on how to make it, just run a dowel through where the screw goes, affix on end and make a cam lever for the other end. For affixing the other end I would probable just use a good fine grained hard wood about 2x2" and long enough to go all the way through, cut a long tenon on all but ~1" of it, drill a hole through the narrow end for the cam and a hole through the stitching pony for the tenon. Slide it through and pin the cam on the end. Nice and easy quick tighten and release.

You could also use a long bolt, use one that is not threaded the full length, cut the head off, file a couple flats on that last inch or so of the unthreaded portion and drill a hole through for the cam. Other end gets a big washer and wing nut, this will give some adjustability for various thicknesses of leather but the all wood cam would probably work just fine.

I suppose the stupid simple way is a bike wheel quick release skewer, but you would have to find one that is threaded its full length (not common) or thread it yourself, even the shortest skewer would be too long.

If I did that and attached some standoffs to the rear, it would also light up a room pretty well from the edge illumination.

This was a rush job with no guidance other than to style it after a softball base so I was winging it as I went.

If I made this project for someone on commission I'm not sure what a fair price would be. I have a lot of time in this one, but that's mainly due to experimenting in acrylic and trying and rejecting a lot of designs along the way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528402

I wouldnt want to own a planer or jointer without one ever again.

They barely need maintenance (I clean pitch off if I'm doing pine or construction lumber a lot), and they're tough as nails. I got mine about a year ago, and I've rotated exactly one cutter, and it probably didn't need it. The machine is a little quieter under load, which is whatever, but the quality of the finish is around 120ish grit or a little worse, so depending on what you're doing, you can very easily get away with sanding only to 150 or 180, like with hard wax oils or whatever.

I get less tearout than even with hand planes (you may still need to scrape some especially tearout prone woods, around here tiger striped sapele with interlocking grain is common and inexpensive, and that stuff tears out like crazy with straight knife cutters or all but the lightest hand plane touch).

Initial cost may seem high but a set of blades is $40 or thereabouts, and if you hit some knots or a nail they're sometimes unrecoverable.

I can also plain perpendicular against the grain- not really recommended, as the finish will be abominable, but sometimes you have to thickness plane a part- and if you do that with straight knives, you get long ribbons that will jam the blower and choke a dust collector to death. With carbide cutters you get little chips that are so much more easily managed and will not stop your dust collector.

They are in the intermediate term a money saver and worth getting out the gate if you can swing it. If you get the smaller diameter head installation is slightly easier but you are restricted in cut depth. I honestly don't think that is a big deal at all (I've popped 20A breakers with the dewalt with full size heads, never with the smaller) and I'm always doing lots of small passes rather than big anyway. If you want to take off a quarter inch a pass, get a three phase machine...

for violins / cellos, the difference in quality is not so much the sound quality. The big difference is how easy it is to play. >>2528599

Lowes and homey d will sell you dimensioned lumber. Normally the "nicest" thing they have is red oak. It will probably be pretty flat and straight, maybe not straight off a planer flat, but pretty good. All boards move with moisture, temp, and acclimatization so it isn't reasonable to expect a board not prepared on site to be perfect.

But it will probably be good enough for a glue up.

That said, a decent hardwood lumber vendor will dimension rough cut lumber for you on site for far less. For reference, my local lowes has a red oak board at $51 for an 0.75"x5.5"x8' board. That is 2.75 board feet, for $18.5 per bd/ft.

My local hardwood vendor is $3.45 for select (nicer) grade red oak per board foot, and they will s4s (joint, straight edge, and plane both sides for $0.40 per bdft, and I think I've seen them do it for free when business was slow. So, somewhere between a quarter and a fifth of the price per board foot.

So if you have a good hardwood store near you, go to them. Your prices may not be the same, but they will beat the big boxes.
