posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528589
Factories work towards an average, small shops work to the individual qualities.

In a factory they just say each part is such and such dimension and call it good, this results in most instrument falling into an acceptable range for the quality they are targeting with a certain number of each batch going to the extremes of either complete garbage or amazing. In the small shop they try and get the most out of each bit of wood, the best possible instrument for the given materials and the luthiers skill, the dimensions of any given part of the instrument will be worked to a mechanical property instead of a physical dimension. So for a soundboard they will have a range of stiffness and weight which they will work towards and not care if it ends up thicker than expected as long as at it falls into that range for stiffness and weight.

Essentially it means the small shop is more consistent, they have few if any instruments which go to those extremes and when they do get such an instrument it is priced accordingly instead of being priced at its model's price.
>>2528613
Ease of playing is generally a setup issue. Unless you buy direct from the maker and that maker sets up the instrument for you then it will need to be setup when initially bought to suit your style. Playability is a personal thing and a balancing act, higher action increases dynamic range, you can pluck the string harder without it hitting the fret board, but it also means it is harder to fret. If you are playing a piece which requires a large dynamic range than a low action may make it easier to fret but more difficult to achieve that dynamic range.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528602
>The big difference is how easy it is to play.

(Disclaimer: I don't actually "play" any string instrument yet.)

I don't really believe this. Musical instruments, in general, are very subjective. Worse, a lot of them (and violins might be the worst here) seem to be subject to this weird elitist attitude. I'm pretty sure the playability (in the most basic sense) is going to be much more dictated by specific design decisions than overall "quality".

Case in point: I bought literally the cheapest viola I could find on eBay. It was under $40, including shipping, bow, case, and some dirty rosin. I got it mostly as a comparison to an experimental instrument I was/am working on. It's perfectly playable. It doesn't sound all that great, even ignoring my poor playing, but it's not difficult to get a solid note out of. There are things that could be slightly better on that front, but nothing that should really affect price. For example, the notches on the nut were way too shallow, the bridge was set too high, and the fine tuners were garbage. All fixable for little or no cost, but I didn't exactly expect much for $40 to begin with, so whatever. From what little I've seen, issues like this generally don't exist in even lower-end stuff (my sister's violin didn't have problems like this, and was under $200).

To the specific point that >>2528613 was asking (factory vs "handmade"), there should be literally no difference. There isn't, fundamentally, any difference between a factory and a "workshop". If you're doing production work in a workshop, the difference between the two is nebulous and vague in the first place. Regardless of whether you have something being assembled by a line of 20 people or one guy in a leather apron, the only thing that's going to make a difference (and this applies to literally everything ever made) is whether or not the one(s) making the instrument give a shit about the end product or are only in it for the paycheck.

>>2528668
Yes, and the reason is that before circa WWII steel was an art more than a science and as a result there was wild variance in quality which means you needed to compensate for potentially poor edge retention for planes primarily used in heavy production work. With modern steels like A2, PM-V11 or Shiro-/Aogami #1/2 you can keep an absurdly sharp edge for a full day of work AND these planes aren't being used on production lines but for specialty pieces and by hobbyists.
If you want to do production flattening with hand tools then the most important compensatory feature isn't a chip breaker but a corrugated sole for the dramatic reduction in friction meaning you don't have to keep waxing the plane. For someone who makes few pieces of bespoke furniture it's not exactly a problem to run the blade over a strop twice a day or running a block of paraffin down the sole every now and again.
Different times, different design considerations.

>>2528821
lol.

Corrugated soles also failed for good reason, wood soles have far less friction and the corrugated sole was an attempt to win over those who were dedicated to wooden planes, it failed just like every other attempt. Took the rise of portable power tools to kill the wooden plane and essentially kill the metal plane as well. But friction is not that big of a deal until the final pass when everything is essentially perfect and you are just removing the last of the tool marks, the rest of the time the variation in the wood's surface keeps friction low enough to not be an issue. Not to mention there is no reason to use a jack plane for the finishing pass, a finely set smooth plane will do the job just fine and even an infill smoother with all its weight will have less friction than a corrugated sole jack plane.

Up until WWII the primary market for steel planes was production/professionals, steel planes were too expensive for the guy who just needed something for the odd job about the house. Corrugated soles and low angle jack failed because the people who used these planes to make their living hated them.

Chip breaker is very important despite what you think, no matter how great the steel in your blade is or how corrugated the sole is it can not make up for the lack of a chip breaker, it is a specialty plane and very useful for when you need it but makes a poor general purpose plane.

Also, if you are in production you do not sharpen your blade, you just swap the blade out/switch planes and sharpen at the end of the day or let the shop boy/local sharpener take care of it. You are literally speaking out your ass and just making shit up.

got some BLO and mineral spirits, also have like half a block of beeswax left from another project. can I just melt down the wax and add it to the BLO/spirits mixture and have it penetrate into the wood? or do I need a special paste wax for that

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529024
Normal way would be chop up the beeswax and dissolve it into the solvent, then add the linseed. My standard recipe is to take a cheese grater to the beeswax, throw some in a jar about 1/4 full of turpentine, keep adding wax until no more will dissolve in, add a little more turpentine to dissolve that last bit of bees wax and the double that volume with linseed.

This mixture would only be used straight for softwoods and very absorbent hardwoods like poplar, would thin abit for denser hardwoods like what you see in an ax handle. General practice for thinning, add enough turpentine that it almost completely soaks into the wood. No idea if beeswax will dissolve into mineral spirits, never tried it. Melting it down can work but more suited to making paste waxes which are not the best for things like ax handles since they do not really soak into the wood very well and would not help if beeswax does not dissolve in mineral spirits since it would just reharden after it cools back down.

But as I said, no reason to over complicate an ax handle finish. Thin the linseed oil with the spirits just enough that it almost completely absorbs into the wood, apply a few coats over a week or so and you will be good. Give it a fresh coat every spring and fall.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529135
To hand rub bees wax just rub the block of wax onto the wood and then use some canvas or leather or most anything of the sort and rub hard until it is worked in. Your goal is to generate enough heat with the rubbing to work it well into the grain. Main trick is to learn how much wax to apply, if you put on too much from the start the cloth/leather you use to rub it in with will just drag and you will not generate enough heat to get it to work into the grain. Start out light with the wax and work your way up to learn how much to apply. This is my standard finish for my planes, holds up well, nice in the hand and is one of the finest looking matte finishes out there.

You can do this with most waxes, paraffin wax does a good job as well and is a bit easier to work in. Carnauba will give a more durable finish but you will get a serious work out rubbing it in, hard stuff with a higher melting point than other common waxes.

Steel wool is not a good material for this, it will leave bits of itself behind stuck in the wax unless you go fairly coarse and then it is better at removing the wax/wood then applying it. What works best depends on the wood, for hardwoods I generally use a nice thick bit of saddle leather or canvas, the thick leather is great for getting into details since you can use the edge but this will not really be an issue on something like an ax handle. Canvas and the like has the drawback that eventually it picks up so much wax that it no longer works, but the you just use that piece to apply wax to raw wood and grab a new piece for rubbing it in, switch back and forth between the two after that, by the time the new one has picked up too much wax the one used to apply wax to raw wood will have given up enough of its wax to start rubbing in again.

For an ax handle I would use a long strip of canvas, go at it like you are shining shoes, will go quickly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529225
Penetration is about protection, a finish that primarily sits on the surface is easily damaged which lets moisture in, grain sucks that moisture into the wood well beyond that damage and it has to evaporate out through the surface. The areas where the surface is still protected by finish slows that evaporation which leads to rot. Deeper the finish goes the less moisture can be sucked in at sites of damage.

Someone who stores their ax in a climate controlled garage and only takes it out on nice days to chop some firewood will not really need to worry about this and no finish will probably be fine. But if you are the sort who stores their ax in a shed and likes to take it out for long walks in the forest, then it will get wet and absorb moisture, having better protection will help keep that handle in good shape for many years. A few coats of thinned oil over a week is not all that much work, maybe 10 or 15 minutes total, not exactly a labor intensive.

But it is an ax handle and essentially a consumable, they are made to be easily replaced for a reason. Personally I see the finish on such things being more about giving the handle a bit of attention a few times a year, go over it with a close eye looking for signs of a split starting or the like to make sure the head is not going to go flying off into the brush or the lake next time I swing it. Splits can be tough to see sometimes, especially when they are just starting or up by the head which keeps them tight until it no longer does and the split turns into a break.

>>2529856
>Why raw and not boiled linseed oil? Doesn't raw take forever?
Yes, raw will take around 6 months to dry. Raw has the advantage better penetration, but it is very impractical to build up a film finish with raw so less protection against surface damage.

Raw will soak in deeper than even thinned boiled which is great for things which often get wet assuming you make sure it has mostly dried before you get it wet since the swelling of the wood will squeeze out a good amount of that raw oil if it is still fairly liquid. Both are great and have their uses but neither replace the other. A coat or two of raw is essentially no finish at all, you want to regularly apply weekly coats for months or just give it a good long soak and hang to dry.
>>2530046
>No deadline for wiping off the excess
You shouldn't do that with oils anyways, thin them until they soak in and only leave the wood look damp, then apply a coat a day just until it starts to build up on the surface. if you want the wood look/feel then stop there, if you want a film finish give another coat or two.
>One undiluted coat is all thats needed for indoor furniture.
That is pretty much zero protection, all it does is slightly slow down moisture absorption at that point. Fine if you live a 24/7 climate controlled life and never open your windows but for everyone else such a finish will just shorten the life of the joinery.

Put some raw oil on a glass plate, see how long it takes to dry. Take a scrap of wood and cut it in half, finish one half as you outlined and then submerge both in water for a few seconds, compare. This is all very easy to demonstrate.

It is perfectly fine as a test and most woods will absorb less moisture from a quick dunk than they will from a month of high humidity as most of the temperate world experiences once or twice a year.

Raw oil was used for centuries and still is, but they used more than one coat. As I said, a coat a week until the wood won't take anymore or soak and hang. Either way, avoid exposure to water and high humidity for the first ~4 months since it absolutely will squeeze oil out if the wood swells much.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2524503
It would be dumb to pretend that no VOCs present health/ environmental hazards (not that anyone's done that) but it's equally dumb to lump any and all VOCs together as health/environmental hazards or to pretend that restrictions on them and off-gassing levels are based on the hazards of direct exposure-

"...the regulations that we have promulgated for VOCs in architectural coatings and consumer products are in place only because many VOCs photochemically react in the atmosphere to produce ozone, a component of smog."

To be clear, that doesn't mean direct exposure is "safe"-

"some chemicals that are toxic are exempt from the VOC regulations because they are not considered to be photochemically reactive. Therefore, some products that are labeled as "no VOC" or "low VOC" under the CAA can actually contain volatile organic chemicals that are toxic, sometimes at high levels.

In addition, the concept of lowering "total VOC" (TVOC) does not always assure safer products because the individual VOCs that make up TVOC can vary widely in their toxicity. While it is probably prudent to use products with lower VOC levels, it does not assure that the products are any better (and they may even be worse) than products with higher VOC levels."

Point is that "VOC" and "offgassing" get tossed around like they're always a direct threat, but lumber, houseplants, many foods like fruit and humans offgas VOCs.

It’s definitely a subdivision house they built like an assembly line, but almost everything since the 50s was like that. Hell, the original house I grew up in was some cheap suburb they built for parents of boomers in the mid 50s and they were all little 2-3 bedroom houses but people built additions over time.

So of 4 houses, one built in the 50s or 60s, the other was like 60s/70s, those two are similar, and the one built in 89 and 99 are pretty close. The two newer ones have better wiring and electrical it seems, there’s a lot more outlets and they actually have cieling fans and built in lighting where the older two expected you to plug in lamps in any bedroom. The newest house, the ‘99 house, it has to be built to a decent standard because South Florida implemented a ton of rules after Hurricane Andrew in ‘92, although my ‘89 Florida house was much more solid it seemed than the ‘70s house just a few blocks away, but I think it was an middle-upper-middle class home compared to a middle class house in the 70s. The ‘99 house has PVC pluming though, and there’s something I don’t really trust about it. Shit’s easy to repair in lots of situations, but you always have to cut off a chunk that’s cemented which means the original installed pipes get shorter and shorter every time or end up with a bunch of extra connections which means more potential for leaks. Copper has issues though, soldering in tight spots can be tricky, and metal gets corroded over time and may need to be chopped off anyway.

posts.com:
Hello I'm in the process of making an wooden external frame pack but I'm pretty sure my frame is way overbuilt rn; it's made from 2 cm (4/5 of an inch) thick floorboards. I want to make it lighter (it's around 1,1 kg/2,4 pounds rn) but I'm not sure how to do it while keeping the most strength.

I was considering three things : make the wood thinner, cut away some material, or make holes.
I'm thinking that the holes would be the worst because they cut the fibers of the wood and make them much shorter, is it a valid concern ?
What do you think ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528062
All three are viable options but how much to do depends on other stuff we can't see like the de site of the wood and how you intend to fasten the parts together and attach the remaining load carrying parts...but in general-

>make the wood thinner
Where and how much is ok depends on the loads on it and in what direction, and how the parts are joined...too thin and glue joints don't have enough area and screws split things and dont have enough meat to grab.
A lot of light wood structures are lashed together for this reason, a d because the flex in those joints prevents cracking and splittting.
>cut away some material
As long as you aren't taking away material that needs to be there it's a good option, and this gs like rounding off edges let you leave lots of meat at the joints for strength. Not a lot of weight loss for the effort but it all adds up.

>or make holes
Most significant way to get big weight loss, but also high risk of adding fatal weak points, especially in solid lumber. Keep the size under 1/3 of the parts width is a basic rule, and consider loads and potential pressure points when locating them.
For exame on a cross piece that has a bending load applied to the ends, one hole in the middle creates a weak point with a solid lever on either side but four holes spread out equally allow the entire piece to flex more uniformly...as long as both remain within the load limits, the one with more holes is less likely to snap in two, and less total weight means less of the load is the structure.
>I'm thinking that the holes would be the worst because they cut the fibers of the wood and make them much shorter, is it a valid concern ?

That's not how wood fibers and wood strength work, the biggest issue is that solid wood is susceptible to splitting with the grain; holes can make this more likely either from loading or just natural wood movement, especially if the location is wrong. That's why wooden structures that need to be ultralight use plywood.

If you’re going to make holes, use a forstener bit to make sure they are perfectly round and if possible, glue a short piece aluminium or pvc tube inside that matches the hole size. This keeps it a lot stronger and allows for more holes without risking fatigue cracks.

Bent hardwood was the standard for these for a reason. Bend it up from something like ash and you will get a lighter frame that is more durable. Ash is about as ideal as it gets for this, very flexible and it will flex instead of break. Best to lash it together, lashing can flex and move with the load which greatly decreases the chances of the wood failing.

What ever wood is used for snowshoes in your area will be a good choice for the frame, generally it is either some sort of ash or birch which are generally very flexible.

Holes should never be made, they only weaken it and will require making things thicker to compensate for that.

>>2528371
There is no universal "for or against" them that applies in every case, they are simply one option for adjusting the balance between strength and weight considerations in structural members. It should go without saying that caution is warranted any time you might weaken a structure, but it's equally important to consider that removing unecessary weight can actually improve the load bearing capabilities of structures and make them less susceptible to catastrophic collapse under certain conditions.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526889
>THOSE STUPID FUCKS AT CREALITY DON'T INTERRUPT THE PREVIOUS INPUT WITH NEW INPUTS.

This isn't necessarily Creality's fault. It's mostly Marlin's. In a nutshell, Marlin's motion interpreter is almost completely standalone. All of its various routines are parsed as gcode, and then fed into the interpreter to be turned into actual control signals for the stepper drivers. This includes manual movements of the axes. Whatever instructions get sent WILL be executed, as few (if any) functions in Marlin's code have the ability to abort the interpreter.

I'll admit, my knowledge of this is a bit dated. I don't know if they've bothered to fix this in later revisions. If it bothers you that much, get the source code for Marlin (check which version your printer is using and get that one) and you can change the default homing/probing behavior pretty easily.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526616
>Though in this case leaving the mill scale on would;ve reduced the amount it rusted.
Mill scale is way worse to weld through than normal rust, especially as light as that is. And from your description, I suspect the problems during welding were from water/contaminants rather than rust. Carbon steel oxide melts at a lower temperature than the metal, so it actually forms a protective slag on the exposed back sides of open welds like that. The molten oxide does reduce puddle control, but good technique with a sharp electrode and a high-oxygen-scavenger filler like 70S-6 can help a lot.

But yes, you can weld straight into the air with TIG, but clean material and good fitup make lot of practical difference. Especially be sure that the material is degreased and dry.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2526679
>Any ideas? I just changed to PrimaCreator MK8 nozzle, but I am
Swap to a fresh nozzle. If the problem persists, it may be heat creep. Is the nozzle aperture smaller than what you've used in the past? Smaller nozzles produce larger back pressure and a greater tendency for filament to distort (both from back pressure and lower volumetric flow leading to more heating time). I've had an issue similar to what you've described in filaments vulnerable to heat creep like silk PLA and soft TPU, and the solution I found was to increase the air flow at the heat break.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527000
>if you want more heat resistance you should look at PETG/ASA
Yeah, generally. Unless you need extreme heat resistance, in which case a PLA+ made to anneal without distortion (e.g. Volcano PLA) can give you ~180C or so. But that sacrifices the greater toughness/flexibility, fatigue resistance, and UV resistance of PETG/ASA.

>Or that PETG/ASA is better to use than PLA+ in general?
Generally, yeah. Regular PLA has some standout features, among them extreme strength and stiffness (about on par with polycarbonate), very good printability, many aesthetic options, and the ability to anneal it for extreme heat resistance. It has notable drawbacks including very low (as-printed) heat resistance, vulnerability to UV and creep under load, and low resilience. PLA+ typically improves some of the drawbacks while sacrificing some of the strengths, resulting in something that doesn't quite fit the niches where regular PLA shines but which often compares poorly to other filaments like PETG and ASA. The exceptions are more for kinds of PLA+ that target a specialty niche, like the Volcano and silk varieties I mentioned. If the PLA+ you use fits your particular needs, that's great, but those aren't my needs.

>PLA+ is way easier to print than either PETG or ASA
Depends on your setup. PEI on spring steel works great for all three, though ASA benefits from an enclosure.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2527002
>the moment heat reached the inside it would burn through and create a hole
Do you have a foot pedal? Sounds like you were too hot. People have TIG welded razor blades and soda cans together, so square tube shouldn't be hard if you get the settings dialed in.

>cleaned it with ~10% muriatic acid and a brush.
Muriatic acid removes minerals like rust and scale. It doesn't do much about grease. Dish soap, acetone, or a variety of other degreasers works well there. Grinding the surface clean gets everything. Chemical cleaners can leave behind residues that become reactive at welding temps, so it's generally a good idea to at least rinse them off before further processing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527051
no, it'll do it just the same. it's an ester hydrolysis. the difference is with a strong base, it's irreversible. but with a strong acid, it only forms a soap while the pH is low. when the pH returns to neutral, the reaction is reversed and it returns to an oil.
so, for example, if you mixed a fat in a container of acid, it would dissolve. but if you diluted that same solution with enough water (or just neutralized it with baking soda or whatever) the oil would reform and separate out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527218
Ok. I think I got it.
I wasn't returning the nozzle to the 0.00 position after setting the z-offset and leveling the bed.
I figured that the z-axis adjustments in the prepare menu were temporary and got erased when you auto-homed or started a new print.

So, these steps do NOT work:
>auto-home
>prepare->move axis->z-axis
>slowly lower nozzle until proper clearance is achieved
>disable steppers
>level bed with paper or feeler gauge
>go to control->bed leveling->z-offset
>enter z-offset
>store settings
>print

This procedure DOES work:
>auto-home
>prepare->move axis->z-axis
>slowly lower nozzle until proper clearance is achieved
>disable steppers
>level bed with paper or feeler gauge

>*go to prepare->move axis->z-axis*
>*return nozzle to 0.00 position!*

>go to control->bed leveling->z-offset
>enter z-offset
>store settings
>print

Irredeemably dumb design and that step isn't mentioned anywhere that I saw. I can't even find a basic process map for how this shit is supposed to work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527124
>tempering is a layer of plastic sandwiched between glass.
Incorrect. That's laminated glass. Tempered glass is glass which has been heated to softening and then quickly quenched, so that the surface hardens before the interior, and when the interior cools, it contracts, setting up compressive stress on the surface. There are also chemical treatments which do something similar, and these can produce greater surface hardening but typically don't alter the fracture characteristics.

They're both "safety" glass. Laminated glass resists breaking apart into free shards, and tempered glass breaks into confetti that presents a much lower risk of cuts. And they're both much more resistant to breaking in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527575
The viscosity/friction of the plastic in the tube provides resistance for the auger to work against, which generates pressurized output at the nozzle. They don't start or stop on a dime, and retractions are right out, but they can handle a wide variety of pelletized feedstock, and they even mix multiple materials on the fly if desired.

>>2527638
Yeah, though arguably there's more money in 3D modelling for people than in printing. Any old yobbo can send an stl file to a local 3D printing service, but you've actually gotta get that file in the first place. I'd start off looking about the /tg/ communities, they often want complicated aesthetic models. Replacements for expensive OEM parts may well be a good market to get into (cars, whiteware, etc.) also. Making moulds for fibreglass or carbon fibre car aero parts is also a pretty good looking market, though that requires a fair bit of hardware.

If there aren't any printing houses nearby then being a contract printer isn't a terrible idea, but you'd still need to have low enough prices to make you worth picking over getting one shipped from somewhere else. A couple of coworkers of mine have started a business doing this, I give them a 50% chance at folding within 6 months.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527724
>butt them up against each other
The contact surface is going to be a weak point of the material, so a scarf joint will give a stronger connection than a butt joint. The shallower the angle, the better. Even better if you give it a little compression in the tube so that the pieces wedge against each other.

>i think it's a bit retarded to hold a lighter up to teflon.
Teflon melts above 600F. It can't withstand direct contact with an open flame, but there's a pretty big window between the filament melting and the tube taking significant damage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527986
>bambu x1 carbon is same quad filaments
Wrong.
Carbon is setup for more abrasive materials such as CF nylon with a hardened steel nozzle and gearset.
X1 uses PC instead of alu plates.
X1C has additional parts such as the aux cooling fan, carbon filter, 1080p webcam.

What you are talking about is the X1C + AMS combo. But I am pretty sure that AMS works with the X1 and P1P too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528823
>if you step fast enough vertically, could you eliminate the z seam?
The plastic of an extruded line starts and ends as a rounded shape because the plastic spreads radially out from the nozzle. If you bump these start and end rounded shapes together, there will be a divot where they meet because nozzles don't disproportionally shove plastic specifically where it would need to go to leave a smooth profile. You can tune it to leave a pretty small divot, but if you're not doing something like spiral vase mode that eliminates stops and starts, you're going to have some kind of blemish. It doesn't have to take the form of a seam though, and there are various ways to hide or otherwise deal with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528802
>Ender 3
Do you have the part cooling fan on 100%?

On certain ender 3s the hot end fan is hooked to the same PWM channel as the fan used to cool the stepper driver boards(a very retarded, very chinky design flaw). Printing a material such as PETG(where you don't want the fan on at all) will shut off the driver board fan. They overheat, and they start to skip steps. The fix is to disconnect the board fan from that channel and instead wire it into an always on connection.

Pic related happened to me over and over when printing a tool case with PETG. I couldn't figure it out until an anon in these threads told me about the issue. After wiring the board fan to a different post my ender 3 has never skipped a step ever again. This was well over a year ago.

even if you do have the parts fan on at 100% You should still do the mod. 9/10 an ender 3 skipping steps is caused by the boards overheating. Also check for dust inside too. That could also be your issue.

posts.com: I'm thinking about getting an enclosure for my Sovol SV01 to keep the dust. Is it a worthwhile investment?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528901
*to keep the dust out

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528901
An enclosure can be a worthwhile investment for a 3D printer to help reduce dust and other contaminants from entering the printer and potentially affecting the quality of your prints. Dust and other contaminants can accumulate on the print bed and nozzle, causing issues with adhesion and extrusion. An enclosure can help keep the printer environment clean and can also help to maintain a more consistent temperature within the printer, which can be beneficial for certain materials.

Also a relative newfag here (at least when it comes to house stuff), I've found it helpful to just buy things as you need them Because it depends what you're trying to do.
At the very least, get yourself:
>A step ladder
>A longer ladder
>A screwdriver (or set)
>A hammer
>A tape measure
>A spirit level
>Some pliers
You can now assemble furniture and hang paintings. Depending on your garden situation you might also want some basic tools for that.

One thing I'll say is that you probably don't need a drill yet and can get by with an impact driver. Also, Ryobi is great for our application. You probably don't need anything fancier.

Youll soon realize that the cliche of shit breaking all the time just isnt true (unless you bought an actual dilapidated house)
If something breaks, you arent going to be able to "fix" it without going to the hardware store anyways.
Buy the tools you need as you are buying the replacement stuff.

Bare minimum
Multi Bit Screwdriver + Adjustable Wrench + Slipjoint Pliers will do 90% of the random "fixes" (aka tighten something thats loose) in the house.

>>2524206
Screwdriver for bits, as well as a bit set containing at least phillips, flat and hex heads - that will fix ~99% of stuff with screws in 'em.
Hex heads are primarily for furniture, The small umbraco keys that come with that are always shit.

Cordless drill (with percussion if your house has brick walls) for all your mounting needs.
Along goes of course at least drills for wood in various sizes (buy a set). If your house has brick, also get a drill set for brick.

Pliers and cutters for any wiring work.

Tape measure and spirit level.

That will sort out 99.8% of basically anything that needs maintenance & mounting in a house...

>>2518032
Depends on the task, but apparently I am an odd one given the replies so far, but I like ratcheting screwdriver with bits. But it is hard to find a good one, honestly still looking the good one broke after several years and the new versions aren't as good. Lots of them now have hollow handles for storage, but that really weakens it as the handle bends and sometimes even breaks in my hand when I grip too hard, the old metal ones never did that. Reason I still like them is I have had projects where I drive in hundreds and hundreds of screws by hand. I had bits wear out which lead to other problems. By switch to fresh bits as I go I didn't have to keep buying screw drivers which cost more then a box of bits. It also lets me change to other types as the job had 8 screw types, so finding a comfy handle each item was annoying. Lastly the ratcheting helped for some oddly positioned screws, but you want fine gear teeth so you don't waste a lot of the rotation.

I also have regular screwdrivers as well for the more detail work as they aren't loose.

why not both?

Seriously though they're both good for different things. A set is great for heavy duty work, especially if you're dealing with rusty or corroded parts all the time. not really sure why anyone would fight about which one is better. For most people it will never make a difference anyways.
